loans.use: To buy fishing equipment such as spear, goggles and swimming suits, a new canoe and a torch used for fishing.

loans.name: Ailua

texts.en: Ailua N. I., 48, is married with three children.  She has two years of experience in the Pancake business. She sells to the village people and the public six days per week. She has no previous loan(s) with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 300 Tala (~100 USD).  SPBD loans are Ailua’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. Ailua's loan will be used buy things needed for her business such as sacks of flour, sugar, cooking oil and a large frying pan.

loans.use: Purchase ingredients for her pancake business.

loans.name: Muaau

texts.en: Muaau E., 35, is married with five children.  She has many years of experience in the plantation business. She sells to the village people and the public one day per week. She has no previous loans with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 250 Tala (~ 80 USD).  SPBD loans are Muaau’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. Her husband does all the work while she helps him with other tasks. The loan will be used purchase sacks of fertilizer and gromozones for the plantation.

loans.use: To buy sacks of fertilizer and gromozones

loans.name: Matane

texts.en: Matane T., 30, is married with four children. She has one year of experience in the plantation business. She sells to the village people and especially to the public four days per week. She has no previous loans with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 250 Tala (~75 USD). SPBD loans are Matane’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. Her loan will be used to buy farming equipment such as knives, spades, a wheelbarrow and an axe. The leftover will be used to buy sacks of fertilizer.

loans.use: To buy farming equipment and sacks of fertilizer

loans.name: May

texts.en: May G., 38, is married with 5 children.  She has 5 years of experience in the Taro Plantation and Vegetables business. May sells to the school, village people and public 4 days per week. She has 1 previous loan with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 80 Tala (about 27 USD).  SPBD loans are May’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. Her loan will be used to buy timber and cement for renovation of her home.

loans.use: To buy timber and cement for home improvement.

loans.name: Saing

texts.en: Saing K., 52, is a widowed mother of four children who are single. Three of them are employed as local farmers and the other one studies in the secondary school. K. currently cultivates rice crops, which she can plant every two seasons a year, including dry season and rainy season. Beside this, she raises a few pigs from her home. K. is applying for a loan to build a pigpen and to buy more piglets to raise. The family resides in Pursat Province, Cambodia.

loans.use: To build a pigpen and to buy more piglets to raise.

loans.name: Ruqaiya Asghar Ali Group

texts.en:
My name is Ruqaiya and I’m a citizen of a city named Kot Radha Kishan in Pakistan. I own a two-room brick house and have been living in it with my family for the last nine years. I am the mother of two sons. Both of my sons work in a factory on a monthly wage. My husband has a dairy business. My husband and I get milk from the buffalo and sell to the community and milk shops. Presently, we have one buffalo and I’m applying for a loan to buy another buffalo for my husband’s dairy business.

I’m the group leader for two other women from my locality. Sugran baji and Shakeela baji each want a loan to buy buffalos for their dairy business.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy another buffalo for the dairy business

loans.name: Malofou

texts.en: Malofou L., 47, is married with 4 children.  She has 2 years of experience in the pancake business. She sells to the village people and public, 5 days a week. She has no previous loans with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 150 Tala (about 51 USD).  SPBD loans are Malofou’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. Malofou's loan will be used to buy sacks of flour, cooking oil, bottle of syrup and a sack of sugar. Her older daughter helps her with the business.

loans.use: To buy ingredients for her pancake business.

loans.name: Opetela

texts.en: Opetela F., 55, is married with 7 children.  She is just starting a business as a baker. She sells to the general public 7 days per week, and has 1 previous loan with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 600 Tala (about 250 USD).  SPBD loans are Opetela’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks.

loans.use: sack of flour, sack of sugar, barrow of oil, gas stove, pots

loans.name: Shaista Parveen Nazim Ali Group

texts.en:
My name is Shaista parveen and I’ve been a citizen of a city named Kot Radha Kishan in Pakistan for the last 10 years. My husband's name is N. A.. He runs a dairy business. Basically, my husband and I are cousins and our families are farmers. Their families were also farmers and they taught us about the agriculture profession. We are both maintaining our family’s legacy. My husband and I both handle our dairy business. Presently, we have two buffalos. I’m applying for a loan to buy a buffalo to expand our dairy business.

I’m the group leader for three other women from my locality. Kaniz Fatima baji, Zareena baji and Nasreen baji each want a loan to buy buffalos for their dairy businesses.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy buffalos for the dairy business

loans.name: Mrs. Sovann Phang Village Bank Group

texts.en: Eleven people living in Preaek Pang village in Kandal province comprise this village bank loan, and they will use the loan for various purposes. Mrs. Sovann P. is 46 years old and is the president of the village bank group. She is also a vegetable seller in the local market. Her husband, Mr. Et Vuthy, is a farmer who owns a plot of land to cultivate vegetables. He needs to purchase more seeds to sow on his field. So, Mrs. Sovann P. decided to ask for a loan to buy ginger seed. She hopes to increase their income and improve her family living conditions with this loan. She has eight children, three of whom are employed in a garment factory, two of whom are laborers, and the remaining three are enrolled in the local school.

loans.use: To buy ginger seed to grow on their field.

loans.name: Mrs. Sarorn Leong Village Bank Group

texts.en: Mrs. Sarorn L. is president of a village bank, formed by a group of eight people who all live in Preaek Pang village in Kandal province. All the members of the group will use the loan for different purposes. Mrs. Sarorn L. is a tobacco seller. Aside from this business, she is a farmer who owns a plot of land on which she cultivates rice. In her plantation, she faces an obstacle which is that her field is infertile, and this badly affects her crop. In order to deal with this problem, she decided to ask for a loan to buy fertilizer. She intends to use the rest of her loan to buy gasoline to pump water to irrigate the field, which will make her crop more productive. Her husband, Mr. Long Pang, is a construction worker. Mrs. Sarorn L. is 52 years old and the mother of six children, one of whom is a cow breeder, another three of whom are laborers, and the rest are attending the local school.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and gasoline for an irrigation pump.

loans.name: Faananafu

texts.en: Faananafu I., 32, is married with 2 children.  She has 2 years of experience in the vegetable garden and plantation business. She sells to the village people and the public 4 days per week. This is her first loan with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 200 Tala (about 120 USD).  SPBD loans are Faananafu’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. Her loan will be used to buy things needed to upgrade both her vegetable garden and her plantation, such as sacks of fertilizer, chemicals, wheelbarrow, axe, knives, gloves and weed-killer. She wants to buy all these things in order for her business to become more successful.

loans.use: To buy supplies and tools needed for her two agricultural businesses.

loans.name: Ferila

texts.en:
Ferila E., 46, is married with five children. She has two years of experience in the vegetable garden business. Ferila sells to village people and the public six days per week.

Ferila has no previous loans with SPBD. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 300 Tala (~ USD).

SPBD loans are Ferila’s only access to capital because she was not able to qualify for a loan from traditional banks. The loan will only be used to buy things for her business.

loans.use: Purchase supplies for gardening business.

loans.name: Rose

texts.en: Rose E. is currently in the business of selling tomatoes and smoked fish and is requesting a loan to open a shop.  Rose is 30 years old and is married to a peasant. She has no children.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a house  BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To open a shop

loans.name: Sarah Grace

texts.en:
Sarah Grace put a small piggery in her backyard. She likes pigs because it helped her address the growing needs of her family. She is 37 years old, married to a farmer and has four children studying in school.

She is planning to start a sari-sari store someday. She thinks that aside from pigs, she needs to venture to another line of business to augment their limited income.

Sarah is asking a loan of Php 6,000 from CEVI. She will use the loan to buy additional piglets for her piggery and feed for her pigs. The loan will truly help Sarah grow her business more and to start her plan for sari-sari store.

CEVI helps Sarah sustain her pigs. She receives credit assistance, training and insurance coverage services, which CEVI gives to all their clients.

loans.use: Purchase feed for pigs and additional piglets.

loans.name: Esther

texts.en:
Esther S. is currently in the business of selling maize flour. She is requesting a loan to build a store for flour at the selling point. Esther is 30 years old and widowed. She has four children, who all go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a house.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services. These are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations.

BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted toward returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Build a store for flour at the selling point

loans.name: Amelinda

texts.en:
Amelinda B. grows pigs for a living. She started her business 2 years ago and is convinced that hog raising is one of the most profitable business to do. Before, she worked on a farm and got paid for all her services, but she was not content to just work and get paid. She wanted to have a business of her own to be able to save money for her future family. She is 25 years old and still single.

Amelinda is requesting a loan of Php 6,000 from CEVI. She will use the loan to buy feeds to grow her pigs. She will also use some of the loan to buy additional piglets to grow her little piggery.

CEVI is a nonprofit organization that helps people, especially the poor, to start and have their own business. CEVI provides credit assistance, training, and insurance coverage to all their clients.

loans.use: To purchase pig feed and additional piglets

loans.name: Kadamala

texts.en:
Kadamala K. is currently in the business of selling at a hotel and is requesting a loan to buy necessities for the hotel. Kadamala is 32 years old and is married to a teacher. She has three children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay school fees for her children.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services. These are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.

In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted toward returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Buy necessities for the hotel

loans.name: Hellen

texts.en:
Hellen A., currently in the business of selling charcoal, is requesting a loan to buy a motor-bike to transport her product to market.  Hellen, 30 years old and married to a security guard, has four children, all students.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a house.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  

In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations, with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To buy a motor-bike to transport charcoal to the market

loans.name: Cynthia

texts.en:
Cynthia J. has a sow. She started her business after she married. She is 36 years old and has 5 children. Her husband is a farmer. Together, they manage their business to support their family's needs. Aside from pigs, they also grow vegetables in their backyard. They water them every day and use the proceeds from their harvest to pay for their other needs.

Cynthia is asking a loan of Php 6,000 from CEVI. She will use the loan to buy additional piglets and feed to grow her piggery. She has regular buyers of her pigs. The loan will truly help her grow her business and earn more income to pay for schools, electricity, and food for her family.

CEVI is reaching out to help more pig growers sustain their livelihood. CEVI provides all their clients with credit assistance, training, and insurance coverage services to help their small businesses grow.

loans.use: To purchase pigs and feed

loans.name: Melchor

texts.en:
Melchor V. is engaged in the pig business. He has a sow which bears piglets that he sells to other pig growers. Raising pigs is a common livelihood in his area. People love pork so much, which maintains the high demand for meat. Melchor has regular buyers of his small pigs. His pig business is what he uses to support his parents. He is 34 years old and still single. Someday, he will marry and that is why he started to save for his future family.

Melchor is requesting a loan of PHP 6,000 from CEVI. He will use the loan to buy feed for his pigs. The loan will help him grow his pig business. He is interested, also, to venture into other possible income areas. In that way, he believes he could better help his parents and his siblings.

CEVI is a non-profit organization that helps people, especially the poor, to start-up and have their own business. They not only provide credit, but training and insurance coverage as well.

loans.use: To purchase feed for his pigs

loans.name: Galilaya Group

texts.en:
Grace, a livestock keeper in the Tengeru neighborhood of Arusha for the past three years, currently earns an average monthly profit of $90. She works at her business for six hours each day.  Grace is requesting her third loan from BRAC Tanzania to purchase more animals in order to increase her current stock. She is hoping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to enlarge her business.  

Grace, 43, is the married mother of five children, ages 23, 20, 17, 13 and 9. She will be sharing this loan with her fellow group members, Sion and Aikande, each of whom has her own small business in Arusha.

loans.use: To buy more animals in order to increase her current stock.

loans.name: Eden Group

texts.en:
Anastazia, who has owned a small grocery store in the Tengeru neighborhood of Arusha for eight years, currently earns an average monthly profit of $90 working 12 hours per day.  She is requesting her third loan from BRAC Tanzania to buy more grocery items for the store, hoping that through this loan her profit will increase and she will be able to enlarge her business.  

Anatazia, 33 years old, is married and has two children: ages 10 and 3.  She will be sharing this loan with her fellow group member, Rose, who also owns a small business in Arusha.

loans.use: To buy more grocery items for her business.

loans.name: Ziad

texts.en:
Ziad is 33 years old and lives with his wife and child in Tripoli, northern Lebanon. He has owned a coffee and juice shop for 15 years, and has requested a loan of $2000 USD from Kiva partner, A. Majmoua, in order to purchase a fridge and fruits for his shop.

Ziad has been a microcredit client for four years now and has always paid on time. His previous loans helped him improve his coffee shop and start the juice business. He is successful in his work because he knows how to treat his customers. When he first started his business, he didn’t face difficulties. Ziad decided to work in this line of business due to his experience and his enjoyment of the work. In the future, he plans on changing the décor of his shop.

loans.use: To purchase a fridge and fruits for his shop

loans.name: Mohamad

texts.en:
Mohamad is 51 years old and lives in Tripoli, northern Lebanon, with his wife and their three children. He has owned a grocery store for seven years, and has requested a loan of $1000 USD from Kiva partner, A. Majmoua, in order to purchase merchandise for his store. This is the first time that Mohamad has requested a loan.

Mohamad went into the grocery business because he wanted to improve his financiA. situation. When he first started his store, he didn’t have the necessary start-up capitA.. Mohamad is successful in his work because he knows how to treat his customers, who include friends and neighbors amongst others. In the future, he plans on expanding his business.

loans.use: To purchase merchandise for his store

loans.name: Franklin

texts.en:
Franklin S. is a 33-year-old family man with four children. He owns a small piggery business by which he hopes to provide for his family's needs. He has a sow that bears piglets, which he sells to other pig growers in his village. He has been in this business a long time because, aside from the fact that he enjoys the work, he has earned a reasonable profit from raising pigs.

Franklin is asking for a loan of 6000 PHP from Kiva partner, CEVI. He will use the loan to buy more feed for his pigs, and believes that the loan will really help him grow his piggery business. Franklin is also interested in venturing into other lines of business as a means of paying his children's tuition and other school fees. More about CEVI CEVI is a non-profit organization that helps people start and own their own business. CEVI gives its clients the credit assistance they need, and also provides training and insurance coverage to further support its clients' businesses.

loans.use: To purchase feed for his pigs

loans.name: Mohammad

texts.en:
Mohammad, 26, lives with his wife and their child in Tripoli, northern Lebanon, where he has worked as a car painter for 18 years. He is requesting a loan of $2000 USD from Al Majmoua in order to purchase paint for his work and to start a new business selling cars. Mohammad has been a microcredit client for five years now and has always repaid on time. 

His previous loans helped him to improve both his garage and financial situation. His knowledge and experience make Mohammad very skilled in his work, and his clientèle includes friends, neighbors and others.  He embarked upon this business because he wanted to have an independent livelihood, and in the future plans on improving his business by selling car paints.

loans.use: To purchase paint for his work and to start a new business.

loans.name: Giselle

texts.en:
Giselle is a 53 year old woman who lives in Tripoli, northern Lebanon. Giselle has owned a shop for fourteen years. Giselle sells beauty products, faux bijoux and accessories.

Giselle requested a loan of $1500 from A. Majmoua in order to purchase merchandise for her shop, like faux bijoux. This is her second cycle and she has always paid on time.

Her previous loan helped her improve her business. Giselle is speciA. because she has a nice variety of accessories and knows how to treat her clients. Her customers are friends, neighbors and others. When she first started her business, she didn’t face difficulty. Giselle decided on doing her business because she likes it and wanted to be independent. In the future, she plans on expanding her business by selling souvenirs and gifts.

loans.use: Purchase merchandise for her shop.

loans.name: Roger

texts.en:
Roger B. owns a small farm in his village. He is 38 years old and has four children. When he is not busy on his farm, he drives a tricycle, a passenger transport, that can carry a maximum of three people. He has a wife, Melanie B.. They work together and grow crops to support the needs of their family.

He is requesting a loan of Php 6,000 from CEVI. Roger will use the loan to buy fertilizers and quality seeds. He will also try venturing to another line of business. In that way, he could be able to contribute well to the family income.

CEVI is non-profit organization that helps people start and have their own business. CEVI provides their clients with credit, training and insurance coverage.

loans.use: Purchase fertilizer and seeds.

loans.name: Alice

texts.en:
Alice is a 49 year old woman who lives in Tripoli, northern Lebanon with her husband and their five children. Alice has owned a grocery store and a small bakery for nineteen years. In her bakery she makes “Mankoucheh.” Mankoucheh looks like a folded pizza and the most common toppings are zaatar (thyme), jebneh (cheese) and lahm bi ajin (minced meat). You can eat it anytime of the day, but somehow it tastes better in the morning.

Alice requests a loan of $2000 from Al Majmoua to purchase merchandise for her store and raw material for her bakery. This is the first time that Alice has requested a loan.

Alice is special in her work because she is known for her Mankoucheh. Her clients are her friends, neighbors and others. When she first started her business, she had some financial issues because she didn’t have enough cash. Alice decided to start her business because she wanted to supplement her family’s income and do independent work. In the future, she plans on expanding and improving her business.

loans.use: Purchase raw material for her bakery.

loans.name: Mat

texts.en:
A small-size stone house and a grocery store in the Phsa Lach Village of Phnom Penh City belongs to Mrs. Mat D.. 

Mat, 26, is a grocery seller.  She sells her wares to neighbors in the village, including cooked ingredients, sweets, plastic goods etc.  She generates a daily income of $4 to help feed her family.  To help with the family's living expense, her husband is a building worker.  The couple has two teenage children who are going to school. 

To increase her stock of groceries, Mat requests a loan to buy more produces to sell.  As another revenue source, she purchases fresh fishes to sell at the marker.

loans.use: Buy more groceries to sell.

loans.name: Adriana

texts.en:
Adriana D. is engaged as a rice farmer. She has a one-hectare farm which she has tilled for 43 years. She is now a widow. Adriana has laborers who works on her farm. She has seven children who also help her manage her rice.

She is asking for a loan of Php 6,000 from CEVI. She will use it to buy fertilizers and quality seeds for her farm. The loan will truly help her increase the yield of her rice. She is also willing to invest in another line of business to support her family even more.

CEVI helps Adriana grow her business. Now, she enjoys having easy access to CEVI credit assistance, training and insurance coverage.

loans.use: Purchase quality seeds and fertilizers for her farm

loans.name: Ibrahim

texts.en:
Ibrahim, 43, who lives in Nabatieh, southern Lebanon with his wife and their three children, has owned a sewing factory for over ten years. He repairs and sews clothes as well as school costumes, and is requesting a loan of $3000 USD  from A. Majmoua in order to purchase thread and repair one of his sewing machines. This is his second loan and he has always repaid on time.

Ibrahim's previous loan helped him improve both his factory and his financiA. situation. He is speciA. in his work because he does it well, and his clients are schools, clothing traders and others. In the future, he plans on improving his business.

loans.use: To purchase thread and repair one of his sewing machines.

loans.name: Mahmoud

texts.en:
Mahmoud is a 61-year-old man who lives in Nabatieh, southern Lebanon with his wife and their five children. Mahmoud owns a bookstore. He also sells stationery and has a printing machine.

Mahmoud requested a loan of 3,000 US dollars from Al Majmoua in order to purchase merchandise for his bookstore and to repay his debts. Mahmoud has been a microcredit client for eight years now and has always paid on time. His previous loans helped him improve his bookstore business. His clients can be anybody. In the future, he plans on improving his bookstore.

loans.use: Mahmoud will use the loan to purchase merchandise for his bookstore and reimburse his debts.

loans.name: Ahmad

texts.en:
Ahmad is a 45-year-old man who lives in southern Lebanon, with his wife and their two children. Ahmad has owned a mobile phone shop for two years, as well as selling phone accessories. He sells and repairs phones. He requested a loan of 2000 US dollars from Al Majmoua in order to purchase merchandise for his shop. This is the first time that Ahmad has requested a loan.

Ahmad is special in his work because of his punctuality. His clients are his friends, neighbors and others. When Ahmad first started his business, he faced competition. He decided on doing his business because he wanted to improve his family’s financial situation. In the future, Ahmad plans on expanding his business.

loans.use: purchase merchandise for his shop

loans.name: Roza

texts.en:
Roza S. is currently in the business of selling beer and is requesting a loan to open up a shop. Roza is 40 years old and is married to a husband who is a businessman. She has 5 children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a house.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations.

BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The micro-finance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: open up a shop

loans.name: Ali

texts.en:
Ali is a 47-year-old man who lives in Nabatieh, southern Lebanon, with his wife and their seven children. Ali has owned a butcher shop for nineteen years. He requested a loan of $2,000 from Al Majmoua in order to start a new business, a bakery. This is the first time that Ali has requested a loan. 

Ali's first business is a butcher shop. He is special in this work because he has good meat. His clients come from around his region. When he first started his business, he didn’t have enough start-up capital. He decided to start a new business because he wanted to improve his family's financial situation. In the future, he plans on expanding his business and starting the new bakery.

loans.use: To open a bakery

loans.name: Botobagnim

texts.fr: Monsieur P. réside dans le quartier de d’agoè assiyéyé, il  est célibataire et lutte fort pour gagner sa vie, ainsi il a ouvert depuis 2007 une boutique de vente de produits d’alimentation générale, il a appelé sa boutique " ETS VENEZ VOIR". Il a une très bonne façon d’accueillir sa clientèle ce qui lui permet d’attirer de jour en jour des clients. Le stock de marchandises dont il dispose actuellement ne lui  permet pas de répondre à la demande de sa clientèle. Il sollicite de WAGES un prêt pour acheter des boîtes de conserve, des cartes de recharges, 10 sacs de riz et 10 bidons d’huile de 25 litres.
texts.en:
Mr. P. lives in the neighbourhood of Agoè Assiyéyé. He is single and works hard to make a living. In 2007 he opened a general food store which he called "Venez voir" ["Come See"]. He has a very good manner with his customers which allows him to gain new customers daily. He does not currently have enough stock to satisfy the demand of his customers. He is asking WAGES for a loan to buy canned goods, prepaid phone cards, 10 bags of rice and 10 25-litre drums of oil.

Translated from French by Laure Kwon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy general foodstuffs

loans.name: Kokou

texts.fr: Monsieur  est un homme très travailleur qui exerce depuis 2007 le commerce de cartes de recharges et d’eau minérale, il est marié avec une femme qui est commerçante et avec 02 enfants. C’est avec le revenu de son commerce qu’il subvient aux charges de sa famille. Il veut agrandir son commerce pour pouvoir mieux vendre et répondre à la demande de ses clients c’est pour cela qu’il s’adresse à WAGES pour solliciter un crédit pour acheter des cartes de recharges togocel, 100 FANVIVA, et 20 sachets d’eau minérale.
texts.en:
Kokou is a hard-working man who has sold mobile phone cards and mineral water since 2007. His wife is also an entrepreneur and they have two children. He supports his family with the income from his business. Kokou wants to expand his business to meet the customer demand. For this reason he has turned to WAGES to request a loan to purchase TogoCel mobile phone cards, 100 FAN VIVA and 20 bags of mineral water.

Translated from French by Joyce ., Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of mobile phone cards, mineral water and FAN VIVA

loans.name: Joice

texts.en:
Joice D. is currently in the business of selling beer and local brew and is requesting a loan to open up a bar as a sales point. Joice is 40 years old and is married to a husband who is a peasant. She has 4 children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay school fees for her children.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations.

BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The micro-finance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: open up a bar

loans.name: Abra

texts.fr: Y. Abra  exerce depuis 2007 le commerce de produits d’alimentation générale et de céréales, elle a commencé depuis peu le commerce de charbons de bois, actuellement elle voudrait agrandir son stock de charbons de bois et de céréales, elle sollicite de WAGES un crédit pour acheter 17 sacs d’haricots, 20 sacs de maïs et 30  sacs de charbons de bois. Elle est mariée  a un monsieur qui est chauffeur, elle a 02 enfants, avec le revenu de son activité elle aide son mari dans les charges du foyer
texts.en:
Since 2007, Abra Y. has been selling food staples and cereals, and also, since recently, charcoal. At this time, she would like to bolster her stock of charcoal and cereals, and she's therefore seeking a loan from Kiva's partner WAGES to buy 17 sacks of beans, 20 sacks of corn, and 30 sacks of charcoal. She's married to a gentlemen who is a driver, and she has two children. With the profits of her business, she helps her husband with the family expenses.

Translated from French by Patrick Stadelmann, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy 17 sacks of beans, 20 sacks of corn, and 30 sacks of charcoal

loans.name: Raquel

texts.en:
Raquel R. is a pig grower. She is 35 years old and has three children. She has a sow and piglets. She has invested a lot in hog raising because she finds it a profitable business. Her husband, Benjamin R., is a farmer. While waiting for the pigs to grow, they also grow root vegetables in their backyard to help them sustain their family.

She is requesting a loan of Php 6,000 from CEVI. She will use the loan to buy additional piglets and feed. The loan will definitely increase the size of her business. In that way, she can better support her family and her children's educational needs.

CEVI is a non-profit organization that helps people, especially the poor, to start and maintain their own business. CEVI provides their clients credit, training and insurance coverage to help their small businesses grow.

loans.use: To buy feed and piglets

loans.name: Falilatou

texts.fr: Depuis 2005,  cette dame a  commencé le commerce  de vente d’ignames, l’igname  est un tubercule très utilisée dans la cuisine togolaise pour préparer le fufu qui est un plat très apprécié par 80% des togolais. Les tenanciers de restaurant viennent s’approvisionner chez elle. Son stock de marchandises est épuisé, pour pouvoir se réapprovisionner elle demande à WAGES un crédit pour acheter 20 calebasses d’ignames. Elle est mariée et a 02 enfants.
texts.en:
Since 2005, this woman has been selling yams (a tuber popular in Togolese cooking, used to make a dish called "fufu" that is very much appreciated by 80% of Togolese). Restaurant owners get their supplies from her. She's currently out of stock, and in order to resupply, she's seeking a loan from Kiva's partner WAGES, to be used to buy 20 "calebasses" (a container made out of hollowed out and dried calabashes) of yams. She's married and has two children.

Translated from French by Patrick Stadelmann, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy and resell yams

loans.name: Ruth

texts.en:
Ruth has been a milk seller in the Tengeru neighborhood of Arusha for 10 years. She belongs to Sayuni Group loan. She currently earns an average monthly profit of US$ 35. Every day she works at her business for 8 hours.

She is requesting her second loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more milk for re-sale. She is hoping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business

Ruth is 45 years old, married, and has six children: ages 24, 23, 20, 18, 16 and 14. She also cares for two additional dependents.

loans.use: To buy more milk for re-sale

loans.name: Ushindi Group

texts.en:
Doris owns a small shop in the Tengeru neighborhood of Arusha. She currently earns an average monthly profit of US$ 90. Each day she works at her business for 12 hours.

She is requesting her third loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more items to increase her current stock. She is hoping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business.

Doris is 31 years old, married, and has two children, ages 10 and 8. She will be sharing this loan with her fellow group member, Fides who has her own small business in Arusha

loans.use: To buy more items to increase her current stock

loans.name: Sugran Bashir Ahmad Group

texts.en:
"My name is Sugran and I’ve resided in a city called Kot Radha Kishan for the past 20 years. I’m a 40-year-old married lady and my husband's name is B. A.. He is a driver and drives a 32-seat local bus. I’m an uneducated lady but I always place value on education. I am the mother of two kids: one girl and one boy. My daughter reads in 8th standard and my son reads in 6th standard. I operate a sewing business. I have been doing this work for the past 4 years. I take orders from my relatives and my neighbors.

I use my income to pay the school fees for my kids and to share the financial burden of my husband. I have successfully repaid my two loans from Asasah (a micro-finance institute in Pakistan). Now I am applying again for a loan to buy an auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle), because my husband wants to quit bus driving.

I am the group leader for two other women from my locality. Suraiya baji and Sharifan baji each want a loan to buy a buffalo for their dairy business."

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy an auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle)

loans.name: Rey

texts.en:
Rey P. is currently constructing a pig fence to start a new business for his family. He wants to grow pigs and sell them later to the meat traders in their village. He is 31 years old and has three children. He is a family man who wants to change his family's life, a father who has dreams for his children.

He is asking for a loan of Php 6,000 from CEVI. He will use the loan to buy feed for the pigs. The loan will help provide him a livelihood. In that way, he can pay for all the family's daily expenses, including school.

CEVI is a nonprofit organization that helps people, especially the poor, to start and maintain their own business. CEVI provides their clients credit, training and insurance coverage to help their small businesses grow.

loans.use: To purchase pig feed

loans.name: Kosar Sabir Group

texts.en:
Kosar S. and her husband have lived in the city of Kot Radha Kishanin the Punjab province of Pakistan for the past 11 years. Kosar is a very hardworking lady. In addition to all her family duties, she runs a vegetable selling business out of a room of her house.  Her husband has had a fruit selling business for the past 6 years. He sells his products from a cart in the community. Kosar successfully repaid her first loan from Asasah (a microfinance institute of Pakistan). Now she is applying again for a loan to buy seasonal fruits for her husband’s fruit selling business. 

This is a group loan. Kosar is the leader of this group, which consists of her and two another women from her locality. Asma Nazir wants a loan to buy a buffalo for her milk selling business. Shazia S. wants a loan to buy clothes for her cloth selling business. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy seasonal fruits for selling

loans.name: Bashiran M.aftab Naz Group

texts.en:
Bashiran baji has been a citizen of a city named Kot Radha Kishan in Pakistan for the past 12 years. Her husband, M. N., runs a grocery shop in the community. Bashiran baji is the mother of two sons. Both of her sons work in a factory for a monthly wage and give half of their income to Bashiran baji. She invests their income in a committee, and plans to marry them off with the committee amount. Bashiran baji is applying for a loan to diversify her husband’s grocery shop into a grocery store.

Bashiran baji’s group includes one other woman who lives in her locality. Nargis baji wants a loan to buy a buffalo for her milk business.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy groceries

loans.name: Merlinda

texts.en:
Merlinda L. is a farmer. She raises pigs and grows rice. She is 53 years old and single. She is a strong woman and capable of doing hard chores like farming and harvesting. When she is not busy in her piggery and rice farm, she works as a photographer. She is working very hard to save money for her needs.

She wants to avail herself of a loan of Php 5,000 from CEVI. She will use the loan to buy feed for her pigs. She will also use some of her loan to buy fertilizers for her farm. The loan will truly help her grow her pig business and improve the soil condition of her farm. In that way, she believes, she will have more harvest on her farm and better income from her pigs.

Merlinda is shown in the photo with her pigs. Some people may mistake her as a man because she dresses and behaves in very masculine manner.

CEVI is a nonprofit organization that helps people, especially the poor, to start and maintain their own business. CEVI provides their clients credit, training and insurance coverage to help their small businesses grow.

loans.use: To buy pig feed and fertilizer

loans.name: Rani Imtiaz Group

texts.en:
Rani baji, 33, is married and lives in Kot Radha Kishan, Pakistan. She owes a two-room brick house and has been living in it with her family for the past 14 years. Rani baji belongs to a poor family. Her father had a wish to give his children a good education but, unfortunately, this didn’t happen. Rani baji made a promise to herself that she will complete her father’s wish by giving  her own children a good education. She has three children: two sons and one daughter. All of her children are attending school. Rani baji’s husband is I.. He has an animal skin selling business. He sells the skins to the factories to earn an income. He has been in this profession for the past four years. Rani baji operates a sewing clothes business. She does this work to pay for the education expenses of her children, because her husband’s income is very little and hardly meets the household expenses. She is applying for a loan to expand her husband’s animal skin selling business by buying more animal skins.

She is the group leader of four other women from her locality. Hakim baji wants a loan to buy wood to sell. Nasreen baji and Zahida baji each want a loan to buy buffalos for their dairy businesses. Asma baji wants a loan to buy bricks to sell.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy animal skins

loans.name: Sakina Abdul Sattar Group

texts.en:
Sakina baji, 39, is married and has lived in Kot Radha Kishan, Pakistan for the past 19 years. Her husband is A. S.. He works in a factory and receives a monthly wage. Sakina baji is the mother of six children: two sons and four daughters. Her elder son also works in a factory and receives a monthly wage. The other children attend a school located near the house. Sakina baji embroiders dresses on orders that she collects from the clothing shops. She makes a good income from her business. She does this work to improve the living standard of her family. She is applying for a loan to buy materials (beads, colored thread, and cloth) for her decorative embroidery business. 

She is the group leader of three other women from her locality. Zubaida baji, Azra baji, and Maroofa baji each want a loan to buy buffalos for their dairy businesses. 

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy embroidery supplies

loans.name: Irshad Qurban Ali Group

texts.en:
I. baji is a wife of Q. A.. She has lived in Kot Radha Kishan, Pakistan for the past 19 years. Her husband is a mason by profession. She is the mother of four children: three sons and one daughter. Her elder son works in a factory on monthly wage. The next son works as a salesman in a departmental store. The younger two are enrolled in school. I. baji sews clothes to earn an income. She sews clothes to improve the financial condition of her family, because she knows that her husband has a financial burden and his income is very little. Her husband appreciates her love and support. I. baji is applying for a loan to buy mason tools for her husband. 

She is the group leader for two other women from her locality. Rashida baji and Sabra baji each want a loan to buy buffalos for their dairy businesses. 

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy mason tools

loans.name: Maqbool

texts.en: Maqbool baji has lived in Kot Radha Kishan, Paksitan for the past 16 years. Her husband is M. P. and he is a painter by profession. He paints doors, windows, and houses. He only goes to work when people call him to paint their houses. He has four years of experience in this profession. Maqbool baji sews clothes. She takes orders from her neighbors. She sews clothes to pay their utility bills. She is applying for a loan to buy paint brushes for her husband’s paint business.

loans.use: To buy paint brushes

loans.name: Ali

texts.en:
Ali is a 25-year-old-man who lives in Beirut, the capital of Lebanon, with his wife. Ali owns a coffee shop. He sells all kinds of hot drinks, cold beverages and "nargileh." The nargileh (also known as “shisha” in Egypt) is an ancient tradition enjoyed by the people of the Middle East. A tall (or short) water pipe is used to smoke fruit-flavored tobacco. Nargileh is enjoyed in cafes across the Middle East, and is beginning to gain popularity in the U.S., Europe and other countries. Ali requested a loan of $2,000 from Al Majmoua in order to purchase merchandise for his coffee shop. This is the first time that Ali has requested a loan. 

Ali is special in his work because his coffee shop is a nice and cozy place. His clients are his friends, neighbors and others. Ali decided on doing his business because he wanted to improve his financial situation. In the future, he plans on improving his business.

loans.use: To buy merchandise for his coffee shop

loans.name: Ndiouga

texts.fr: Monsieur Ndiouga W. vend du bois à Thiès, Sénégal.  Avant de commencer ce travail, il travaillait à Dakar comme menuiser ébéniste.  Il a déjà reçu un crédit auprès de l’IMCEC et il l’a remboursé mais les remboursements étaient un peu en retard.  Cependant, IMCEC et Kiva croient qu’il peut bien rembourser ce deuxième crédit avec son nouveau commerce.  Avec ce crédit il va acheter du bois pour vendre et soutenir sa femme.
texts.en:
Mr. Ndiouga W. sells wood in Thiès, in Senegal. Before starting this business, he used to work as a furniture maker in Dakar. He already benefited from a loan from Kiva's partner IMCEC, which he did repaid, although the repayments were a little late. Nevertheless, IMCEC and Kiva believe that he will be able to repay this second loan without problems, thanks to his new business. With the loan, he will buy and resell wood, in order to support his wife.

Translated from French by Patrick Stadelmann, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy and resell wood

loans.name: Aloune Thiam

texts.fr: Monsieur Alioune Thiam M. est un commerçant marié qui habite à Thiès, une ville située à 70 kilomètres de Dakar, la capitale du Sénégal.  Il est jeune, mais il a commencé de faire le commerce depuis très longtemps.  Avant, il gérait une alimentation générale, mais actuellement il vend des fruits et il fait la navette entre Walo et Thies pour acheter des oignons et du riz et les revendre en gros.  Avec ce crédit il va acheter ces produits et utiliser les revenus pour soutenir sa famille.
texts.en:
Mr. Alioune Thiam M. is a married merchant who lives in Thiès, a city located 70 kilometers from Dakar, the capital of Senegal. He's young, and yet he's been in this business for a very long time. Previously, he used to run a grocery store, but now he sells fruits. He also travels to Walo and back to get onions and rice supplies, that he resells wholesale. With this loan, he will get such supplies, and use the profits to provide for his family.

Translated from French by Patrick Stadelmann, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy onions and rice

loans.name: Mor

texts.fr: Monsieur Mor N. est un menuisier métallique, il est marié et a des enfants. Il habite à la cité Senghor de Thiès. Il aune grande expérience du métier depuis 25 ans  et il est à son premier prêt. Il travaille sur commande et compte aménager son atelier avec ce prêt pour mieux satisfaire ses clients.
texts.en:
Mr. Mor N. is a weldor who works on commission. He's married and has children. He lives in the Cité Senghor in Thiès. Having been in this business for 25 years, he's very much experienced. He's seeking his first loan to outfit his workshop to better satisfy his customers.

Translated from French by Patrick Stadelmann, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To outfit his workshop

loans.name: El Hadji Mamadou

texts.fr: Monsieur El Hadji Mamadou G. est un mécanicien qui veut aussi se lancer dans le commerce de pièces détachés. Il est célibataire et habite au quartier cité Lamy de Thiès. Il a son propre atelier depuis 12 ans à la gare routière et avec ce prêt il veut renforcer son activité qui consiste à la vente de pièces détachés. Il est à son premier prêt et compte rembourser normalement pour augmenter son porte feuil dans l’avenir.
texts.en:
Mr. El Hadji Mamadou G. is a mechanic who also wants to start selling spare parts. He's unmarried and lives in the Lamy neighborhood in Thiès. For 12 years, he's been running his own workshop near the bus station. With this loan, he wants to bolster his spare parts business. This is his first loan, and he counts on it to increase his profits in the future.

Translated from French by Patrick Stadelmann, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy and resell spare parts

loans.name: Ibou

texts.fr: Monsieur Ibou G. est un tailleur marié qui a son propre atelier depuis 30 ans. Il dispose une bonne clientèle, et il sollicite ce prêt pour acquérir une machine à coudre marque gros fil pour mieux confectionner les nouveaux modèles des femmes. Ses revenues lui permettent d’entretenir sa famille et aussi de renforcer son activité de tailleur.
texts.en:
Mr. Ibou G. is a married tailor who has had his own workshop for 30 years. He has a numerous clientele and he is requesting this loan to acquire a sewing machine for heavier fabrics so as to be better able to sew up-to-date fashions for women. His income allows him to support his family and also to bolster his tailoring business.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of a sewing machine

loans.name: Numa

texts.en:
Numa J.  is currently in the business of selling at the hotel and is requesting a loan to buy food items for the hotel. Numa is 25 years old and is married. Her husband is a driver. She has two children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay the school fees for her children. 

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Buy food items

loans.name: Tindelo

texts.en:
Tindelo M. is currently in the business of selling at a hotel and is requesting a loan to buy chairs and tables for the hotel. Tindelo is 40 years old and is married with a husband who is a businessman. Tindelo has 6 children all of whom go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a house for her family.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To buy chairs and tables for the hotel

loans.name: Khudoiberdi

texts.en:
Cattle farming is an economic activity dedicated to the raising of animals in order to generate revenue from the animals and the products they provide. Khudoiberdi has earned a living raising cattle since he was young. Now married, he has five children who, according to Khudoiberdi’s words, are his reason for living. 

The low incomes earned by people in this rural region aren't enough to maintain a family, and for this reason Khudoiberdi works enormously hard to provide a better standard of living for his wife and children. He now urgently needs to buy animals such as cows and calves and is therefore requesting a loan of $600 USD for a period of 12 months. Be an important part of the growth of Khudoiberdi’s business.    


More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is perhaps best known for its rich history, which includes:  its role as a key post along the Silk Road; the end of Alexander the Great's rule; and its famous great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets including Rudaki, Ibn Sina (Avicenna), Firdousi, Omar Haiyam, Jomi, Mavlavi Rumi and many others. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC.  Even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions. 

However, Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics.  The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy.  In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous, and only 7% of the land is arable.  These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment, forcing hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia.  While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty. 

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing of young cattle.

loans.name: Iskandar

texts.en:
G. Iskandar has worked for many years in the difficult business of raising cattle. He is an exemplary husband in that he always tries his hardest to provide food for his wife and the three children in their home. After purchasing his cattle, Iskandar provides them with all the right conditions for their growth: taking care of their food and protection and making sure they don’t get lost. Once they’re fully mature, Iskandar sells them in his area and also provides their milk for sale. Currently he needs to purchase cattle to raise and for this reason is turning to IMON International to obtain a loan of $600. Iskandar thanks Kiva for the support that Kiva provides to small entrepreneurs.

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is perhaps best known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road; the end of Alexander the Great's rule; and with it’s famous great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets as: Rudaki, Ibn Sina (Avicenna), Firdousi, Omar Haiyam, Jomi, Mavlavi Rumi and many others. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing young cattle

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary M., currently in the business of selling tea and bread, is requesting a loan to buy more sugar, coffee and bread for sale.  Mary, the 30-year-old wife of a businessman, has three children, all attending school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a house to rent. 

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  

In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To buy more sugar,coffee and bread for sale.

loans.name: Kokui

texts.fr: Madame K. est une résidente du quartier de djidjolé, elle est mariée à un chauffeur, elle a 03 enfants, elle exerce depuis 1990 le commerce de produits d’alimentation générale, ce qui fait qu’elle a une parfaite maîtrise de son activité, sa clientèle est importante et par conséquent  la demande  élevée, son stock actuel de marchandises ne peut couvrir cette demande, elle sollicite de WAGES un crédit pour acheter des marchandises pour rehausser son stock.
texts.en:
Mrs. K. lives in the Djidjolé neighborhood. She is married to a chauffeur and has 3 children. She has been selling grocery products since 1990, which means that she is knowledgeable in this business. Her clientele is numerous and since the demand for her goods is high, her present stock of merchandise is not able to meet the demand. So she is asking WAGES for a loan to buy merchandise to increase her stock.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of groceries for re-sale

loans.name: Davlat

texts.en:
H. Davlat is a native of Penjikent, Tajikistan, and has stayed in her native land to progress there. That is why three years ago she decided to move forward with raising livestock. She began with just one cow and now has many.

Every morning, Davlat goes out early so that her beloved cows may graze among the hills all day in hopes that they return happy and satisfied. Davlat is motivated to continue in this arduous work by the thought of her five children, who along with her husband, also help her with the cows.

In order to succeed in her business, Davlat and her family look to nourish the animals and keep them happy, in hopes of ultimately selling them at a just price. Thanks to her continued activity in her occupation, Davlat and her family are able to sustain themselves and this fills Davlat with great satisfaction. However, with the support of this loan, she would now like to purchase more species of livestock to increase her clientele. With your support, Davlat will be able to accomplish her business goals and thus, help fund the education of all five of her children.

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is perhaps best known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It is also known for its famous great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets as: Rudaki, Ibn Sina (Avicenna), Firdousi, Omar Haiyam, Jomi, Mavlavi Rumi and many others. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. loans.use: Purchasing young cattle

loans.name: Merijina

texts.en:
Merijina S. is currently in the business of selling maize flour and is requesting a loan to open up a shop. Merijina is 38 years old and married to a peasant. She has four children who all go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay school fees for her children.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services. These programs are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.

In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted toward returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Open up a shop to sell maize flour

loans.name: Samariddin

texts.en:
Samariddin K. is a humble man who works as a cattle farmer. He is motivated to work harder every day in order to provide for his young son. Cattle farming requires a lot of physical work, crossing long distances under the sun to transport the animals from one point to another. This can cause illnesses and weaken the body. Nevertheless, Samariddin continues to work hard and has come to IMON International to request a loan that will allow him to purchase young bulls to raise and sell in his area.

More about Tajikistan and IMON International:

Tajikistan
Tajikistan is perhaps best known for its rich history and diverse culture, which is a mix of the Islamic faith, Soviet influence, and Central Asian traditions. It served as a key post along the Silk Road and marked the end of Alexander the Great's extensive rule. It was the birthplace of the great Persian poet Rudaki and famous Islamic philosopher Ibn Sina. And it is home to epic mountain passes, communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC.

In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need.

loans.use: Purchase young cattle

loans.name: Simino Kossiwa

texts.fr: Etant une femme dynamique et travailleuse, cette dame a commencé à exercer depuis 2007 le commerce de maïs et de charbons de bois, le dynamisme dont elle fait preuve faite qu’elle est très connue dans son commerce, le stock dont elle dispose actuellement est presque épuisé, elle a déjà obtenu de crédit de WAGES, elle sollicite son second crédit pour se réapprovisionner avec 03 sacs de charbons de bois et 05 sacs de maïs. Elle est mariée et a 02 enfants, son mari est militaire. Avec le revenu de son commerce elle participe aux charges du foyer.
texts.en:
As a dynamic and hard-working woman, this lady began in 2007 to sell maize and charcoal. She is well-known in her sector and thus, the stock that she has presently is almost expended. She has already had one loan from WAGES and is now requesting her second to buy 3 sacks of charcoal and 5 sacks of maize for re-sale. She is married and has 2 children; her husband is a soldier. With the income from her little business, she participates in supporting her family.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of maize and charcoal for re-sale

loans.name: Zaini

texts.en:
Zaini S. is married with six children, adults and younger, who live with him. He works in the agriculture and livestock industry. His strength is in raising livestock, but he is dedicated to cultivating his crops through fumigation and care in order to obtain a good harvest. He would like to invest in his livestock business by purchasing cows to obtain milk for sustenance and commercialization. He seeks support from IMON International to help him move his business forward. With your help, Zaini can get ahead.

More about Tajikistan and IMON International:

Tajikistan

loans.use: Purchase young cattle

loans.name: Yoromia

texts.en:
Yoromia J. is 40 years old and married, with six children who go to school. Her husband is a driver. Yoromia sells tomatoes and would like a loan to open up a shop. With the extra profits that result from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a house.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education and human rights and legal services that are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs (non-governmental organizations) as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted toward returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: open up a shop

loans.name: Fatou

texts.fr: Madame Fatou N. est une commerçante veuve qui habite au quartier SOM à Thiès. Depuis 1998 elle vend des schandwich le soir et le matin et des petits déjeuners devant chez elle. Elle sollicite ce prêt pour renforcer son activité qui consiste à acheter de la farine, des œufs, de l’huile, du sucre etc., et également d’une machine à coudre pour confectionner des pagnes. Les revenues lui permettent de se nourrir et de payer les depenses de la maison.
texts.en:
Mrs. Fatou N. is a widowed businesswoman who lives in the SOM neighborhood in Thiès. Since 1998, she has been selling sandwiches in the evening and breakfasts in the morning, outside her house. She is requesting this loan to bolster her little business, that is, to buy flour, eggs, oil, sugar, etc., and also to buy a sewing machine to sew "pagnes" (brightly printed African cloth used as sarongs). The income will allow her to feed herself and pay household expenses.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of flour, eggs, oil, and sugar

loans.name: Kholjigit

texts.en:
T. Kholjigit has been dedicated to the business of cattle ranching for the last 10 years. This business requires a lot of dedication due to the fact that is demands a lot of effort to carry out the breeding. This is also true because it requires the strict control of every one of the animals and at the same time feeding and caring for those that are older. It is necessary to emphasize that through this business Kholjigit is able to maintain his spouse and six children. It is because of this he his soliciting a loan through IMON International. The credit will allow him to be buy more animals, which he will raise and sell in the market.

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is perhaps best known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It's also known for its famous great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, such as Rudaki, Ibn Sina (Avicenna), Firdousi, Omar Haiyam, Jomi, Mavlavi Rumi and many others. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low-income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing young cattle

loans.name: Vera

texts.en: Vera is married with one son, who is almost 2 years old. Vera sells office supplies at her own small store in a little city named Luchki. She has been in this business for six years. Her income is not big but it is stable. Vera believes she can make her business grow even more by attracting more clients and increasing sales. She would like to borrow 7,000 UAH to increase her inventory. Vera would spend additional income to raise her son.

loans.use: To increase inventory

loans.name: Fama

texts.fr: Madame Fama F. est une vendeuse de petit déjeuner depuis plus de 10 ans au quartier Mbour 1 de Thiès Elle est marié, et voulant diversifier ses sources de revenues, elle sollicite ce prêt pour se lancer dans le commerce des body et des parfums et aussi renforcer son kiosque pour le petit déjeuner ou elle a une bonne et fidèle clientèle. Les revenues lui permettent de soutenir son mari sur les dépenses familiales.  Madame F. a déjà reçu deux crédits auprès de l’IMCEC et elle les a bien remboursés.
texts.en:
Mrs. Fama F. has been selling breakfast for more than 10 years in the Mbour 1 neighborhood of Thiès. She is married and, wishing to diversify her income sources, she is requesting this loan to begin a little business selling personal hygiene products and perfumes and also to reinforce her breakfast nook business where she has a good and faithful clientele. The income allows her to help her husband support the family. Mrs. F. has already received two loans from IMCEC, and she reimbursed them correctly.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: begin selling perfumes and bolster her breakfast nook business

loans.name: Akossiwa

texts.fr: Madame A. akossiwa est une femme qui est mariée avec un monsieur qui est menusier, elle a 03 enfants et résident dans le quartier d’Amadahomé. Elle exerce comme activité génératrice de revenu la vente de produits d’alimentation générale et de pagnes. Son stock actuel de produits d’alimentation générale est épuisé pour cela elle sollicite de WAGES son premier prêt pour acheter 04 bidons d’huile de 25 litres, 04 cartons de pâtes alimentaires, 02 cartons de boîtes de tomates et 03 cartons de détergents « OMO ».
texts.en:
Mrs. A. Akossiwa is married to a carpenter, has 3 children, and lives in the Amadahomé district. She has been selling groceries and "pagnes" (lengths of brightly colored African print cloth) to earn a living. Her present stock of grocery products is expended, and for that reason she has asked WAGES for her first loan in order to buy 4 jerry cans of 25 liters each of oil, 4 cases of pasta, 2 cases of tinned tomatoes, and 3 cases of Omo detergent.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of groceries for re-sale

loans.name: Afi Holali

texts.fr: A. afi a abandonné en 2003 les études et  exerce comme activité  le commerce de produits GNLD,  elle exerce ce commerce depuis 2004, elle gère bien ce commerce car elle a de petites notions de gestions, actuellement le stock de marchandises dont elle dispose est insuffisant pour répondre à la demA. de la clientèle. Ayant déjà obtenu de WAGES un crédit qui lui a permis de débuter son activité, elle sollicite son deuxième crédit pour acheter des produits GNLD, elle est célibataire et c’est ce commerce qui lui permet de subvenir à ses charges.
texts.en:
A. Afi stopped going to school in 2003 and has been selling GNLD (nutritional, herbal, etc.) products. She has been working at this business since 2004; she runs her little business well, since she knows a bit about management. Presently, the stock of merchandise at her disposal is insufficient to meet the demand of her clientele. Having already received a loan from WAGES that allowed her to start up her business, she is now requesting her second loan to buy GNLD products. She is single and this business allows her to support herself.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of nutritional supplements, etc.

loans.name: Farida

texts.en:
Farida is dedicated to improving her quality of life, and does not scrimp on any efforts to achieve this, as her responsibility as a mother is her major driving force. She has been working for four years raising animals such as cows and sheep. Farida built a small stable in her house in order to do this, and her earnings have made up for her long term efforts to care for these animals. She is very enthusiastic about continuing to raise animals, as this will  permit her to improve her living conditions. Farida asked for a loan of $600 to purchase young cattle for expanding her business. Let’s support this hard-working and talented woman so that she can reach her goals!

loans.use: Purchase young cattle

loans.name: Jane

texts.en:
Jane M. is currently in the business of selling rice,dale and beans at the hotel and is requesting a loan to buy fans and a generator for the provision of fresh air in the hotel .  Jane is twenty-five years old. Her husband is employed as a nurse. She has two children and both of them go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, Jane hopes to be able to open up a supermarket.


BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: buy fans and a generator to provide fresh air in the hotel

loans.name: Andre

texts.en: Andre and his wife have one daughter who is nine years old. He offers taxi services in his city and between cities. He has been in this business for six years. Andre uses his personal car as a cab. His business goal is to pay his car loan and to be able to use the profit from his business to improve his family's living conditions. Andre would like to receive a loan of $950 to purchase a license, buy insurance and pay for minor car repairs.

loans.use: to purchase license, insurance and car repair

loans.name: Akossiwa

texts.fr: Etant  veuve et pour pouvoir subvenir à ses besoins et à ceux de ses deux enfants, elle a associé à son activité de couture  le commerce de pagnes et de tissus dans son atelier qu'elle a appellé « COIN DE GLOIRE », cela lui réussit bien surtout qu’elle profite pour vendre ses pagnes à ses clientes. Ne disposant pas d’assez de stock de pagnes elle sollicite de WAGES un prêt pour acheter 15 pièces de pagnes de haute qualité et 30 tissus.
texts.en:
As a widow attempting to support herself and her two children, Akossiwa E. has been working as a seamstress and at the same time selling "pagnes" (lengths of brightly patterned African cloth) and other fabrics in her workshop that she calls « COIN DE GLOIRE » (Glory Corner).
