The distance to the markets from where she lives is 50 kilometers. She has to do this because life has become very expensive. Bashihron has applied for a loan with Kiva and plans to buy a spring assortment of clothing.

Translated from Russian by Elena Fedorchuk, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy spring assortment of clothing

loans.name: Ahmad

texts.ru: Ахмад работает в коммунальном хозяйстве города Исфары. Ему 61 год, женат. Его единственный ребенок уже имеет свою семью и проживает отдельно от родителей. Ахмад собирается отремонтировать свою квартиру и поэтому давно планировал это. Но после скрупулезных подсчетов увидел, что ему не хватает некоторой суммы денег. Поэтому он пришел в МикроИнвест и подал заявку на займ. Собирается купить доски и шифер.
texts.en:
Ahmad works in a collective farm in the town of Isfara. He is 61 years old and married. His only child already has own family and lives separately from the parents. Ahmad wants to repair his apartment and has been planning this for a long time. But after careful calculation he has found that he is short of a certain amount of money. This is why he has come to MicroInvest and applied for a loan. He plans to buy boards and slates.

Translated from Russian by Elena Fedorchuk, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy boards and slates for home repairs

loans.name: Christine

texts.en:
Christine Y. is currently in the business of selling beer and is requesting a loan to buy more crates of beer to sell. Christine is 40 years old and married. Her husband is an agricultural worker. She has three children who attend school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a bar.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowering the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights. They also deliver legal services through an extensive network of village organizations.

BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs, as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which targets returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To buy more crates of beer to sell.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary A. is currently in the business of selling charcoal at the market and is requesting a loan to open up a shop. Mary is 28 years old and married. Her husband is a cattle keeper. She has two children and her children do not go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a house.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Open a shop

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary K. is currently in the business of selling beer, sugar etc and is requesting a loan to open up a shop.  Mary is 40 years old and married to a soldier. She has five children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a house.
BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To open a shop

loans.name: Cecilia

texts.en:
Cecilia L. is currently in the business of selling beer and is requesting a loan to open up a bar. Cecilia is 26 years old and is married to a peasant. She has three children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a house.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To open a bar

loans.name: Kiden

texts.en:
Kiden R. is currently in the business of selling beer at home and is requesting a loan to buy more beer for sale. Kiden is 35 years old and is married to a soldier. She has six children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a bar.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To buy more beer to sell at home

loans.name: Winifred

texts.en: Winifred A. has been selling milk and rice in Cape Coast since 2004.  She is married with two children. She received her education through vocational school.  Her husband is a goods seller.   She is responsible for paying water and light bills. Her loan will be used to stock up her store with various goods. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to build a house.

loans.use: To stock her store with various goods.

loans.name: Adelaide

texts.en: Adelaide A. is a baker who also sells bread in Kotokraba near Cape Coast, which she has done since 1996.  She is married with 2 children and has received her senior high school degree. Her husband is a mason.  She is responsible for paying school fees and utilities. Her loan will be used to buy flour, sugar and butter for her bakery. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to build a house for rent.

loans.use: To buy flour, sugar and butter.

loans.name: Adjowa

texts.en: Adjowa B. sells oil, tomatoes, and Maggi (stock cubes and seasoning sauce) in Cape Coast, which she has been doing since 2005.  She is single with no children and has received her senior high school degree.  She is responsible for paying her rent and utility bills, and also buying food. Her loan will be used to buy more goods to help fill up her store. She hopes to use the new profits to increase the capital of the business.

loans.use: To buy more goods to sell in her store.

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en: Since 1996, Elizabeth T. has sold various provisions and cosmetics such as powder, perfumes and bomo in Kotokraba near Cape Coast.  She is single with 2 children and has received her senior high school degree.  She is responsible for paying light and water bills. Her loan will be used to buy provisions and cosmetics to help fill up her store with more merchandise. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to build a house.

loans.use: To buy provisions and cosmetics to sell in her store.

loans.name: Peter

texts.en: Peter O. is married with two children and received his senior high school degree. Peter sells shoes in Kotokraba, near Cape Coast, which he has done since 1995. His wife is a hairdresser. Peter uses his income to pay for rent, utility bills and school fees. Peter will use the loan to purchase more shoes to expand his business. With the new profits from his expanded business, Peter plans to buy land.

loans.use: To purchase more shoes to expand his business.

loans.name: Justice

texts.en:
Justice M. sells shoes in Cape Coast, which he has been doing since 1993. He received his senior high school degree and is married with a child. His wife works as a trader. He is responsible for paying rent, school fees and utilities. He will use his loan to buy more shoes to sell and hopes to use the new profits from his business to construct a building.

Behind him and on the floor are the kins of shoes he trades in.

loans.use: To buy more shoes to sell.

loans.name: Samuel

texts.en: Samuel K. is a 48-year-old husband to two and the father of eighteen children. He grew up in Rongo but trained to be a chemist in Migori. Samuel has been in business twenty years and has managed to send the majority of his children to school. He is asking for 30,000 KSH which he will use to stock his shelves as well as to purchase dairy cattle to add extra food security.

loans.use: To buy medicine and dairy cattle

loans.name: Daphine

texts.en:
Daphine A. is a 24 year old mother of one child, a boy, named Toni Braxton (after the singer). Her husband is a driver and though she is not from Rongo, she loves the weather.

She makes her own ice cream and sells it in the open market in Rongo. She mixes water, sugar and flavors, puts them in polythene and freezes them. Her number one flavor is orange. Daphine hopes she can grow her business with this loan of 20,000 KSH.

loans.use: Buy icream suppllies.

loans.name: Eric

texts.en:
Eric O. has sold shoes in Cape Coast since 1999.  He is married with one child and has received his senior high school degree. His wife works as a trader.  

He is responsible for paying rent, utilities, and other household necessities.  Eric's loan will be used to buy more shoes to expand his business.  He hopes to use the new profits from his business to buy land.

loans.use: Buy more shoes to expand his business.

loans.name: Paul

texts.en:
Paul A. is married with two children and has received schooling through junior high school. Paul sells shoes in Kotokraba near Cape Coast, which he has done since 1993. His wife is a seamstress.

Paul uses his income to pay for rent, school fees and utilities. He will use the loan to purchase more shoes to expand his business. With the new profits from his expanded business, Paul plans to buy land.

loans.use: Purchase more shoes to expand his business.

loans.name: Ellen

texts.en:
Ellen A. is single with one child and has received an education through senior high school.  Ellen sells bags, materials and weaves for hair, and has done so since 2007, in Cape Coast.  

She uses her income to pay for utility bills and rent.  Ellen will use the loan to purchase more goods for selling.  With the new profits from her expanded business, Ellen plans to pay for school fees.

loans.use: Purchase more goods for selling.

loans.name: Judith

texts.en: Judith O. is a 26-yearold mother of three children, ages 9, 7 and 4.  She and her husband sell travel-bags in the open air market in Rongo.  She also sells other items like radios and school bags. Judith is asking for 30,000 KSH to expand her business.

loans.use: Buy more items to sell.

loans.name: Robert

texts.en:
Robert H. has been a car dealer and taxi driver in Idan, near Cape Coast, since 2001. He is married with four children and has received a junior high school education. His wife is employed as a trader.

He is responsible for paying utility bills and feeding and clothing his children. His loan will be used to do some maintenance work on the taxi. Robert hopes to use the new profits from his business to buy land and support the his children’s education.

loans.use: Make repairs to his taxi.

loans.name: Augustina

texts.en:
Augustina E. cooks rice and sells it along with perfume and oil in Idan, near Cape Coast. She has done so since 2006. She is married with two children and has received her junior high school degree. Her husband works as a trader.

She is responsible for paying her children’s school fees and house utilities. Augustina's loan will be used to buy provisions for resale and the food she prepares for sale. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to buy land.

loans.use: Buy provisions for resale and food she prepares for sale.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary M. is single and has two children. She has been selling food supplies, such as onions and peppers, in Kotokraba near Cape Coast since 1987. Mary uses her income to pay for pay for rent, utilities, and clothing.

Mary will use this loan to purchase more food supplies to sell. With the new profits from her expanded business, Mary plans to save to buy land for her own house.

loans.use: To purchase more food supplies to sell

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth E. A. is married with five dependent and received basic schooling. Elizabeth is a supplier of palm nuts in Kotokraba near Cape Coast, which she has done since 1979. She supplies them to her customers who are mostly palm oil producers. Her husband is a nurse. Elizabeth uses her income to pay for utilities and the school fees of her children.

Elizabeth will use the loan to buy more palm nuts to supply to her customers. With the new profits from her expanded business, Elizabeth plans to build a house.

loans.use: To buy more palm nuts to supply to her customers.

loans.name: Emmanuel

texts.en:
Emmanuel A. is married with two children and has received technical schooling. Emmanuel sells spare car parts in Swidu near Cape Coast, which he has done since 2005. He also runs a taxi which is generating a lot of income for him. His wife is a store dealer. Emmanuel uses his income to pay for utilities, housekeeping expenses, school fees and rent.

Emmanuel will use the loan to purchase more spare parts for his business and will also use part to make some minor repairs and do maintenance on his taxi. With the new profits from his expanded business, Emmanuel plans to reinvest in the business.

loans.use: To purchase spare parts for his business and make minor repairs and maintenance on his taxi

loans.name: Taleh

texts.en:
Taleh Z. is a successful young entrepreneur aged 18. He started his business at age 16 when he was helping his father and was working as a seller. Now Taleh is experienced enough to run the shop alone. He lives with his parents and takes care of them as they are now on pension. Today his clientele has increased and his grocery has become more popular.

Taleh is asking for a loan so that he can expand the variety of goods that are sold in his store. Taleh is very grateful to everyone who is helping him to achieve success in his business with this loan.

loans.use: To purchase more inventory for his store

loans.name: Ohemma

texts.en:
Ohemma N. sells ladies’ dressing bags in Cape Coast, which she has done since 2002. She is married with two children and received her senior high school diploma. Her husband is a driver. Ohemma is responsible for paying utility bills and buying food.

Ohemma’s loan will be used to buy more ladies' bags for selling. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to support her children's education.

loans.use: To buy more ladies' bags for selling

loans.name: Asef

texts.en:
Asef H. has always been a hard-working man who has made sure, from a young age, that his family never went without their daily bread. He is married and lives with his parents in one house. Asef has a grocery store where he sells different kinds of foodstuffs. With a starting capital of $200, and thanks to his perseverance and dedication, he began this enterprise six years ago. Today this business has become domestic and his wife is also engaged in the business.

Now Asef needs to buy additional foodstuffs to increase his range of goods for sale.  He is ready to work even harder, to make sacrifices and to push every once in awhile to achieve his goal and become a successful entrepreneur. We believe his perseverance and clear vision will become key success factors in his small business.

loans.use: To buy additional foodstuffs to increase his range of goods for sale

loans.name: Juliana

texts.en:
Juliana B. sells second-hand bed sheets and towels in Nkafua near Cape Coast, which she has done since 2005. She is married and has received her senior high school diploma. She is responsible for helping support her children.

Juliana’s loan will be used to expand her used-clothing business. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to buy land.

loans.use: To expand her used-clothing business

loans.name: Juliet

texts.en:
Juliet N. G. is married with three children and has received an education through senior high school. Juliet sells groundnut paste in the Cape Coast area, which she has done since 2002. While Juliet sells her goods, her husband works as a mechanic repairing tires. Juliet uses her income to assist her husband in paying for food, utilities, and clothing.

Juliet will use the loan to purchase more raw materials, such as groundnuts, for the purpose of processing the groundnut paste for sale. With the new profits from her expanded business Juliet plans to purchase land, which one day she would like to use as the place to build a home for her family.

loans.use: To purchase raw materials such as groundnuts, to process them for sale

loans.name: Raset

texts.en:
Raset A. is a successful young man of 25. He is single. Raset began selling fruit and vegetables in a small village of Imishli city. He started his business in 2004. Usually fruit/vegetable markets work in the early part of the day, so Raset has special benefit from his business. He starts his business after 2 o’clock and many people who cannot buy fruits or vegetables in the local market in the morning come to Raset.

Today his clientele has grown greater and his grocery has become more popular. He is asking for a loan so that he may expand the variety of goods that are sold in his store. Raset is very grateful to everyone who helps him to achieve success in his business with this loan.

loans.use: expand the variety of goods

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: purchase more merchandise

loans.name: Gunduz

texts.en:
Gunduz B. is 39 years old. He is married with three children. He is a small entrepreneur who sells various kinds of foodstuffs such as: cookies, candies, soft drinks, juices, macaroni, detergents and many others in his grocery store which he built 3 years ago. Currently Gunduz has about 1200 USD in inventory. His monthly net profit is about US 200.

Today Gunduz is requesting a loan of 1225 USD for the term of 15 months to increase his stock. He is ready to work even harder, make sacrifices and push every once in a while to achieve his goal and become a successful entrepreneur. One of his dreams is that his children might progress by means of their studies, for which he is doing his very best. We believe his perseverance and clear vision will become key success factors in his small business.

loans.use: diversify number of food products

loans.name: Rebecca

texts.en:
Since 2006, Rebecca H. has sold phone card units in the Cape Coast area. She is married with 2 children and received an education through vocational school. While Rebecca is selling her wares, her husband is employed at the University of Cape Coast.

Rebecca uses her income to pay for rent, utilities, food, and her children’s school fees. Rebecca will use the loan to purchase more phone card units in order to expand her business. With her newly gained capital, Rebecca plans to put up a building where she and her family can live.

loans.use: purchase more phone card units

loans.name: Zubia Tajamul Tajamul Hussain Group

texts.en:
My name is Zubia T. and I am a citizen of a city named Lahore, in Pakistan. Lahore is famous for its historical places and for its Punjabi foods. I am uneducated because my parents could not pay for my education. I am married to a man whose name is T. H., and he also lives in Lahore. He runs his own grocery shop in the community. I have three children, all of whom are boys. They are getting an education from a school located near our house. I keep myself busy by embroidering clothes. Through this work I share the family's financial burden and pay the school fees for my children. My family is very happy with my supportive behavior. I am applying for a loan to diversify my husband’s grocery shop. 

I am the group leader of four another women from my locality. Bushra baji wants a loan to pay the remaining installments of her auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle).  Shazia baji wants a loan to buy another sewing machine for her tailoring center. Zubaida baji and Shagufta baji each want a loan to buy garments to sell. 

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: Various, including items for grocery shop

loans.name: Philomena

texts.en: Philomena B. has worked as a hair dresser in Cape Coast since 2002.  She also sells other supplies to assist her business, such as hair creams. She attended school through senior high and is married with one child. While Philomena works as a hair dresser, her husband is self-employed. Philomena uses her income to help pay for the family’s school fees, utilities and food.  She will use the loan to purchase more goods to expand her business. With the new profits from her successful expansion, Philomena plans to buy land, on which her family will eventually build their home.

loans.use: Purchase more goods to expand her business.

loans.name: Nazia  Khalid Rafique Group

texts.en:
Nazia baji is the wife of K. R.. They have lived in Lahore, Pakistan for ten years. The city of Lahore is famous for its historical places and for Punajbi foods. Nazia baji is the mother of two children, one son and one daughter. Both of them are enrolled in school. Nazia baji and her husband made a commitment to themselves that they will give their children a better future, so they work really hard to fulfill their commitment. Her husband sells fruit from a cart by announcing his products in a loud voice in different areas, and Nazia baji embroiders dresses on order. She collects the orders from the cloth shop and gets money for her labor. Nazia baji is applying for a loan to buy materials, including beads and colored thread, for her decorative embroidery business. 

She is the group leader of three other women from her locality. Shumaila baji wants a loan to buy scrap for her scrap business. Razia baji wants a loan to buy a sewing machine for her sewing business. Shagufta baji wants a loan to buy artificial jewelry to sell. 

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee the others' loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: Various, including buying embroidery supplies

loans.name: Philomena

texts.en:
Philomena E. has been selling provisions at Ntsin in Cape Coast, Ghana, for one year.  She is married, and her husband works at a restaurant in the area called Hans Cottage.  Philomena got her education through a vocational school.  She is responsible for paying for her family’s utilities, food and clothing.  Philomena’s loan will be used to buy more provisions with the intention of expanding her business. She hopes to use her newly acquired profits to buy land, on which her family intends to eventually build a home.

She is in the green dress in the photograph.

loans.use: Buy more provisions to expand her business.

loans.name: Anthony

texts.en:
Anthony S. B. sells school bags and suitcases at Kotokraba in Cape Coast, which he has done since 2000. Anthony is single with no children and has received an education through senior high school.  He uses his income to support himself and pay for various living expenses and utilities. 

Anthony will use the loan to purchase more bags and to expand his business. With his newly acquired profits from his successful business, Anthony plans to buy land, where he will eventually build his home.

loans.use: To increase inventory and expand his business.

loans.name: Villa Antacocha Group

texts.es:
El Banco Comunal Villa Antacocha pertenece al Proyecto Wari, las socias son D. la comunidad D. Putica que se ubica a 30 minutos D. Cangallo, en el departamento D. ayacucho, las principales actividades D. la comunidad son la agricultura y en menor cantidad la crianza D. animales.

Las socias realizan diferentes negocios como la venta D. animales, carne, abarrotes en general y la agricultura.

Como es el caso D. maura que es casada, tiene 2 hijos, Maura venD. golosinas, gaseosas actividad que realiza en su casa, desD. que es socia aprendió mucho a través D. las capacitaciones que recibe, su préstamo lo invertirá en la compra D. mas mercadería para surtir su negocio. Maura sueña con ampliar su negocio y tener un negocio mas granD..

Por otro lado Norma es casada, tiene 2 hijos, Norma compra y venD. cereales, tubérculos, algunos D. los cuales los produce ella en sus tierras y también compra D. los demás productores, su préstamo será invertido en la compra D. mas productos que ofrecerá a mas clientes, Norma sueña con tener un puesto estable donD. venda sus productos y ahorrar para la educación D. sus hijos.
Mientras que Juana es casada, tiene 2 hijos, Juana tiene una pequeña tienda D. abarrotes en su casa, negocio que fue creciendo D. poco, su préstamo invertirá en la compra D. mas productos y surtir mas, Juana sueña con aumentar su negocio y brindar una buena educación a sus hijos.

Las socias necesitan diferentes montos D. prestamos como 100 soles, 500 soles, 600soles, haciendo un total D. 7,000 soles D. prestamos en el Banco Comunal. 

Sus prestamos serán invertidos en la compra arroz, azúcar, animales menores, Trigo, cebada.
texts.en:
The "Banco Comunal Villa Antacocha" belongs to the Wari Project, the members are from the community of Putica which is located 30 minutes from Cangallo, in the department of Ayacucho. The main activities of the community are agriculture and some breeding.

The members have different businesses such as sale of animals, meat, groceries and farming. On the other hand, Norma is married with 2 children. She buys and sells cereals, tubers, some of them grown on her own land, and she also buys from other farmers. Her loan will be invested in buying more products to offer to more clients. Norma dreams of having a stable stand where to sell her products and of saving money for the education of her children.

Juana is married with 2 children, she has a small grocery store at home, business that has grown little by little. Her loan will be invested in buying more and varied products. Juana dreams of increasing her business and of giving a good education to her children.

The members need different amounts for the loans such as 100 soles, 500 soles, 600 soles, making a total of 7,000 soles for the "Banco Comunal.

Their loans will be invested in buying rice, sugar, small animals, wheat, and barley.

Translated from Spanish by Lene Struck Christensen, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase rice, sugar, small animals, wheat, and barley.

loans.name: Joana

texts.en: Joana A. M. has worked as a seamstress and trader in Elmina, Ghana for the past eleven years. She sells material, zippers, and other sewing notions. She is married with five dependents, and has received an education through junior high school. Joana’s husband works at a beach resort named Coconut Grove Hotel in Cape Coast. She uses her income to help pay for the family’s light bill and school fees. She is requesting a loan to purchase more sewing materials to sell, which will help her expand her business. Joana plans to reinvest new profits to ensure that her business carries on successfully.

loans.use: Purchase more sewing materials to sell

loans.name: Ernestina

texts.en:
Ernestina A. is married with one child and has received an education through junior high school. She is responsible for assisting the family with paying their bills. She has been selling iced kenkey (a popular drink that is served cold in plastic bottles) and other drinks at the old post office in Elmina since 2005.

Ernestina A. is requesting a loan to purchase milk to make iced kenkey and other drinks to sell. She hopes to use new profits from her business to build a house for her family.

loans.use: To purchase milk to make iced kenkey and other drinks to sell

loans.name: Santa Cruz De Ccechcca Group

texts.es:
El Banco Comunal Santa Cruz D. Ccechcca pertenece al Proyecto Wari, las socias son D. la comunidad D. Tambillo que se ubica a una hora D. la ciudad D. ayacucho, las principales actividades D. la comunidad son la agricultura y  la crianza D. animales.

Las socias realizan diferentes negocios como la venta D. cereales, animales, carne, abarrotes en general, comida, panes y la agricultura.

Como es el caso D. Victoria que es casada, tiene 4 hijos, Victoria tiene una pequeña tienda en su casa en donD. venD. abarrotes, en su banco aprendió mucho a través D. las capacitaciones que recibió, su préstamo será invertido en la compra D. mas mercadería para surtir mas su negocio. El sueño D. Victoria es tener una tienda mayorista y ser feliz con su familia.

Por otro lado Yolanda es casada, tiene 2 hijos D. 16, 10 años, Yolanda venD. comida en su casa, Yolanda inicio poco a poco, su préstamo será invertido en comprar arroz, azúcar por sacos, los sueños D. Yolanda son tener un restaurante, tener mas clientes y ahorrar para los estudios D. sus hijos..

Las socias necesitan diferentes montos D. prestamos como 200 soles, 500 soles, 900soles, haciendo un total D. 4,800 soles D. prestamos en el Banco Comunal. 

Sus prestamos serán invertidos en la compra trigo, cebada, maíz, animales menores, azúcar, arroz.
texts.en:
The Santa Cruz D. Ccechcca community bank is a part of the Wari Project. The members are from the community of Tambillo, which is located an hour from the city of Ayacucho, Peru. The main activities in the community are agriculture and raising livestock. The members carry out different businesses such as selling grains, animals, meat, general groceries, food, bread and agriculture.

This is the case of Victoria, who is married and has four children. She runs a small shop out of her home selling groceries. At the bank, she learned a lot through the training she received. Her loan will be used to purchase more merchandise to better stock her business. The dream of Victoria is to have a wholesale store and be happy with her family.

Another member is Yolanda, who is married and has two children, ages 16 and 10. Yolanda sells food out of her home .She started little by little, and her loan will be used to purchase rice and sugar by the sack. Yolanda's dreams are to have a restaurant, have more clients and save for her children's education.

The members need different amounts of the loan, such as 200 soles, 500 soles, 900 soles, for a total of 4,800 soles for the community bank. The loans will be invested in the purchase of things like wheat, barley, corn, small animals, sugar and rice.

Translated from Spanish by Marty Greenstein, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase items like wheat, barley, corn, small animals, sugar and rice for the members' various businesses.

loans.name: Rebecca

texts.en:
Rebecca A. has been selling building materials like paints in Elmina for eleven years. She is married with two children, and her husband is employed as a trader. Rebeccas is responsible for paying her family’s light bill and her children’s school fees.

Rebecca will use her loan to buy additional building supplies, such as lining bottoms (used to support ceilings) and other items necessary for the building process, which she will then resell. She hopes to reinvest her new profits back into her business to ensure that it is successful for years to come.

loans.use: To buy additional building supplies to resell

loans.name: Esther

texts.en:
Esther A. works as a trader in Elmina, selling food supplies such as gari (fried cassava), beans, and rice, which she has done since 2005. She is married with three children and has received an education through junior high school. While Esther works as a trader, her husband is employed as a plumber.

Esther intends to use the loan to purchase additional provisions and food supplies for resale. With the new profits from her expanded business, Esther plans to save enough money so that she can build a house for her family.

loans.use: To purchase additional provisions and food supplies for resale

loans.name: Alpachaca Group

texts.es:
El Banco Comunal Allpachaca inicia su cuarto ciclo con 16 socias, todas ellas son D. la comunidad D. Alpachaca, distrito D. Chiara, que se ubica a 3 horas D. la ciudad D. Ayacucho, la población se dedica a la agricultura y la ganadería. 

Las socias realizan diferentes negocios como la venta D. animales, abarrotes en general, frutas, muchos D. las socias se dedican a la agricultura  y la crianza D. ganado vacuno, producción D. quesos y leche.

Las socias necesitan diferentes montos D. prestamos como 200 soles, 450 soles, 600soles, haciendo un total D. 8,000 soles D. prestamos en el Banco Comunal. 

Sus prestamos serán invertidos en la compra arroz, azúcar, quesos, abono, remedios, animales.

Los sueños D. las socias son mejorar sus negocios, tener mas ganado, tener mas producción y que sus hijos sean profesionales.
texts.en:
The Alpachaca community bank is starting its fourth loan cycle with 16 members, all of whom are from the community of Alpachaca in the district of Chiara, Peru, which is located three hours from the city of Ayacucho. The population makes a living in agriculture and livestock. The members carry out different businesses, such as selling animals, general groceries and fruits. Many members make a living in agriculture and raising cattle, producing cheeses and milk.

The members need different amounts from the loan, such as 200 soles, 450 soles and 600 soles, for a grand total of 8,000 soles for the community bank. The loans will be invested in the purchase of items like rice, sugar, cheeses, fertilizer, medicines and animals for their businesses. The dreams of the members are to improve their businesses, have more livestock, increase their production and for their children to become successful.

Translated from Spanish by Marty Greenstein, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase items like rice, sugar, cheeses, fertilizer, medicines and animals for their businesses.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary A. is a fishmonger who sells various types of fish at the port in Elmina; she has been in business since 1991. Mary is married with three children and her husband is a security officer. Mary is responsible for helping to pay her children’s school fees as well as the family’s bills.

Mary’s loan will be used to buy more fish with the intention of expanding her business. Mary hopes to use the new profits from her business to buy a plot of land, on which she will eventually build a home.

loans.use: To buy more fish with the intention of expanding her business

loans.name: Muhtaram

texts.ru: Мухтарам 45 лет, она замужем и имеет 1 ребенка. У нее мелкий бизнес. Она продает сигареты, жевательную резинку, конфеты и тп. При этом не имея постоянной торговой точки она каждый раз привозит свой столик с товаром к местам скопления людей во время праздников и свадеб. Там у нее наиболее лучшая касса ее бизнеса. Муж Мухтарам нигде не работает и использует различные способы чтобы заработать. Мухтарам решила немного расширить свой бизнес и поэтому подала заявку на займ КИВА.
texts.en:
Muhtaram is 45 years old, married, and has one child. She runs a small business selling cigarettes, chewing gum, candy and other items. As she doesn't have permanent place to sell at, she she sets up her table and goods where people gather at celebrations and weddings. She has the most business there. Muhtaram's husband is unemployed and finds various ways to make a living. She decided to expand her business a little, and so is requesting a loan from Kiva.

Translated from Russian by Anna Brown, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Business expansion

loans.name: Gladys

texts.en: Gladys O. is a fishmonger and sells her goods at the fish port in Elmina; she has been in business since 2003.  Gladys is married with 3 children and her husband is employed as a driver. Gladys uses her income to assist her husband in paying for the family’s bills.  She will use the loan to purchase more fish for resale. With the new profits from her expanded business, Gladys plans to further her children's education.

loans.use: To purchase more fish for resale.

loans.name: Ekua

texts.en:
Ekua B. is a trader who sells fresh fish and goods, such as utensils, in Elmina; she has been in business since 1999. She is married with five dependents and has received her junior high school diploma. While Ekua sells her wares, her husband is employed as a taxi driver. Ekua is responsible for helping to pay her children’s school fees.

The loan will be used to buy more fresh fish from the fishermen for resale and also to invest in the other goods to expand her business. She hopes to use her newly gained profit to complete the building of her house.

loans.use: To buy more fresh fish for resale as well as other goods

loans.name: Agatha

texts.en: Agatha A. works as a hair dresser at the fish port in Elmina.  She also sells mesh cloth for hair and weave-on hair pieces.  Agatha has been in business since 2003.  She is single with no children and has received an education through junior high school.  Agatha is requesting a loan to improve her hair-styling business. She plans on using her profits to invest in her business and further improve her income and standard of living.

loans.use: To improve hair-styling business

loans.name: Theresah

texts.en: Theresah W. is a trader who sells a local variety of donuts in Elmina, which she has done since 2007.  She is single with four children and has received an education through primary school.  Theresah is the primary breadwinner of the family and uses her income to pay for her children’s basic needs and school fees. Theresah is requesting a loan to purchase items needed to make more donuts and expand her business. She will use her improved income to add to her savings, which will be used to purchase a piece of land where she can build a home for her family.

loans.use: To expand food production

loans.name: Nusrat Mushtaq Group

texts.en:
Nusrat baji is the wife of M. and they have lived in a mid-size city named Vehari, Pakistan for the past ten years. Vehari city is famous for its shrines. She is the mother of three daughters. Her eldest daughter helps her in a clothes-making business. The others are receiving education from a local school. Nusrat baji’s husband works in agriculture. He sells fertilizer and seeds to the other farmers and sometimes takes care of their lands and charge fees. Nusrat baji is applying for a loan to buy fertilizers and seeds for her husband's business.

She is the group leader and there are two others in her group: Razia baji requests a loan to buy groceries for her grocery shop. Nasreen baji requests a loan to buy plastic beads for making plastic bottle caps and shopping bags.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and seeds for reselling

loans.name: Mary

texts.en: Since 1999, Mary C. has been a fresh-fish trader in Elmina. She is married with four children and has received an education through primary school. Her husband is a fisherman and uses his ocean catch for Mary to sell.  Mary and her husband use their incomes to support their children and pay their school fees. Mary is requesting a loan to purchase necessary items needed to expand her business. She hopes to use her improved income to build a home for her family.

loans.use: To expand fish-selling business

loans.name: Nasreen M. Ramzan Group

texts.en:
Nasreen baji is a wife of M. R. and they have lived in a mid-size city named Vehari, Pakistan for the past six years. Vehari city is famous for its shrines. Her husband is an auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle) driver and has been in this business for five years. Nasreen baji is the mother of two children, one son and one daughter who are in school. Nasreen baji sews clothes to pay for her children's school fees because her husband’s income barely meets the financial expenses of the household. She is requesting a loan to change the body of her husband’s auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle) so he can continue to earn his income.

She is the group leader of a group with four other women. Shagufta baji requests a loan to buy fertilizer to sell. Gaman baji requests a loan to buy a donkey cart. Bashiran baji requests a loan to buy scrap for her scrap business. Rukhsana baji requests a loan to buy a buffalo for her animal-selling business.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: For vehicle improvement

loans.name: Parveen M. Aslam Group

texts.en:
Parveen baji has been a citizen of Vehari, Pakistan, for the past nine years. Her husband’s name is M. A. and he has a pesticides-selling business. He has been doing this work for the past four years. Parveen baji operates a clothes-sewing business. She does this work to share the financial burden of her husband. She is applying for a loan to buy pesticides to expand her husband’s business.

Parveen baji is the group leader of three another women from her locality. Hajran baji wants a loan to buy pesticides to sell. Nazia baji wants a loan to buy supplies (lentils, cooking oil and spices) for her food-selling business. Suraiya baji wants a loan to buy groceries for her grocery shop.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy pesticides to expand her husband’s business

loans.name: Zahooran Allah Wasaya Group

texts.en:
Zahooran baji is a widow and resides in a city named Vehari, Pakistan. She owns a two-room brick house and has been living in it with her three children (two daughters and one son) for the past 10 years. With the income from her clothes-sewing business she put her daughters into school and started a shoe-selling business for her son. Her family is very happy and give her respect and feel proud. Zahooran baji is applying for a loan to buy a stock of shoes for her son’s shoe-selling business.

Zahooran baji is the group leader of four other women from her locality. Sahabzadi baji wants a loan to repair her 32-seat local bus. Rubina baji wants a loan to buy groceries for her grocery shop. Zakia baji wants a loan to buy a buffalo for her milk-selling business. Ata Ilahi baji wants a loan to change the body of her auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle).

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy a stock of shoes for her son’s shoe-selling business

loans.name: Kosar M. Nawaz Group

texts.en:
Kosar baji ihas been a citizen of  Vehari, Pakistan for the past 15 years. Vehari city is famous for its shrines. Her husband, M. N., is an auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle) driver. He drives a rented auto-rickshaw. Kosar baji is requesting a loan to buy an auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle) for her husband so that he doesn't have to rent his vehicle and can receive all the income from his labor.

She is the group leader of a group with two other women. Jandodi baji requests a loan to buy an auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle). Manzooran baji requests a loan to buy beams for her shuttering business. 

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy an auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle)

loans.name: Abdufatto

texts.ru: Абдуфатто в первый раз получил в МикроИнвест займ для продолжения строительства своего дома и тогда он купил строительные материалы. Условия кредитования МикроИнвест ему понравились, и так как он занимается бизнесом, он решил получить займ для его развития. Абдуфатто 51 год, он женат и имеет 5 детей. Бизнес Абдуфатто располагается в самом престижном ресторане города, где он арендует бар. В его баре работает 2 человека (на фото продавец). Абдуфатто надеется что полученный займ способствует развитию его бизнеса и он и дальше будет получать кредиты.
texts.en:
Abdufatto's first loan from Microinvest funded the purchase of building materials for continued construction of his house. He liked Microinvest's loan conditions, and since he has a business he decided to request a loan for its development. Abdufatto is 51 years old, married, and has five children. His business is in the city's top restaurant, where he rents the bar. Two people work at the bar (the vendor is in the picture). Abdufatto hopes that the loan will allow him to further develop the business, and that he will be able to continue to receive loans in the future.

Translated from Russian by Anna Brown, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Business development

loans.name: Suraiya Shahadat Mahmood Group

texts.en:
Suraiya baji is the wife of S. M., who lives in a city named Riwind, Pakistan. Riwind City is famous for its shrines. Her husband has a vehicle named “Shahzore” by which he delivers different items (e.g., fruits & vegetables and construction supplies) from one place to another and thereby earns income. He has been in this profession for the past 10 years. Suraiya baji is applying for a loan to repair her husband’s vehicle because its engine is creating trouble. 

Suraiya baji is the group leader of four other women from her locality.  Parveen baji wants a loan to buy material (mirror, razors, and chairs) for her beauty salon. Razia baji wants a loan to buy wood for her furniture-making business. Zahida parveen baji wants a loan to buy thread to sell. Sugran baji wants a loan to buy ingredients (lentils, cooking oil and spices) for her food business. 

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: For vehicle repairs

loans.name: Sherali

texts.ru: Недавно Шерали исполнилось 30 лет. Он женат и имеет 2 детей. Вместе с отцом имеет бизнес по продаже магнитофонных кассет и DVD дисков. В МикроИнвест ранее кредитовался отец Шерали, затем он постпенно передал бизнес своему сыну Шерали. Торговля налажена и прибыль остается достаточная, чтобы прокормить семью. За товаром Шерали ездит на оптовые рынки, которые расположены в 170 километрах от его дома. Недавно ему предложили открыть еще одну точку по продаже дисков и подсчитав свои возможные расходы Шерали решил подать заявку для получения займа.
texts.en:
Sherali recently turned 30. He is married and has two children. He and his father run a business selling audio cassettes and DVDs. The father received a loan from Microinvest earlier, but has now gradually handed over the business to his son Sherali. Sales are steady and the income remains sufficient to support a family with. Sherali goes to wholesale markets 170 kilometers from his house to buy goods. Recently it was suggested that he open another sales location, and after calculating expected expenses Sherali decided to apply for a loan.

Translated from Russian by Anna Brown, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Business expansion and opening of a new shop

loans.name: Najma Nazir Hussain Group

texts.en:
Najma baji is a wife of N. H., who lives in a city named Riwind, Pakistan for the past 10 years. Riwind City is famous for its shrines. Her husband runs a salon where people come to him for hair cutting and for shaves. He has 5 years of experience in this business. Najma baji operates a sewing clothes business to pay off the utility expenses. She is applying for a loan to buy materials (scissors, razors) for her husband’s salon. 

Najma baji is the group leader of four other women from her locality. Mussarat baji wants a loan to buy an iron to sell. Shazia baji wants a loan to buy bangles to resell. Ayesha baji wants a loan to buy thread to sell. Bilquis baji wants a loan to buy wood for her furniture-making business.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy materials for a salon

loans.name: Zainab M.akram Group

texts.en:
Zainab baj is a citizen of a city named Riwind, in Pakistan. She is thirty-six years old and married. She has been living in this city for the last fourteen years. Her husband's name is M., and he is a driver of a rented auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle). The owner gives him very little income even though the owner knows that her husband works really hard. Zainab baji decided to apply for a loan to buy an auto-rickshaw for her husband so that he can get the entire amount of income from his work.

Zainab baj is the group leader of four other women from her locality. Qubra baji wants a loan to buy artificial jewelry to sell. Nawab baji wants a loan to buy thread to sell. Suraiya baji and Bashiran baji each want a loan to buy seasonal vegetables to sell. 

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee the others' loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: Various, including buying an auto-rickshaw

loans.name: Mohammad Dahood

texts.en:
Mohammad Dahood is the son E.. He lives in Kabul, Afghanistan. He is 47 years old, married, and has six children. Two sons work with him in his general store and the others are students. He works very hard to earn money to pay for his family's living expenses.
 
Mohammad wants to purchase additional materials for his shop and make it larger. He has requested an individual loan of 50000 Afghani for the term of 12 months to buy all the materials for the shop. 

He would like to say that Kiva is the best.

loans.use: To buy materials  for his shop

loans.name: Asmatalah Group

texts.en:
Asmatalah is the leader of this four-person group. All four would like to receive money for their businesses. They have requested a loan of 40000 Afghani for the term of eight months. 

Kharma Sharyn and Farzana each want a loan for their vegetable businesses. 
Yasamen wants a loan to buy a new sewing machine for her tailoring business.
Asmatalah wants a loan for his general store so he can to expand his business.   

With this loan, these entrepreneurs can improve their businesses. They are very happy for the opportunity to have these loans in Afghanistan. These loans help the poor people and they want to say "Thanks" to all the Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To expand his business

loans.name: Zalay Kha Group

texts.en:
Zalay kha is the group leader of the Zalay kha group. There are four members in this group. Each of them would like to receive money for his/her business.

Zalay kha and Rahayla want to take a loan for their carpet-weaving business. Narghas wants to take a loan for her husband’s business of selling barker shop. M. Faryad wants to take a loan for his businesses. They all want to see expansion and progress in their businesses and want to earn more money to support their families. With this loan, they can make their businesses larger, support their families better and make a better future for themselves and for their families. They are really happy with this loan process in this poor country.

loans.use: To increase their business

loans.name: Shukria

texts.en: Shukria is the daughter of A. Q.. He lives in district 8 in Kabul, Afghanistan. She is married and has three children. She and her children live in a small house; most of it was destroyed during the winter because of snow and rain. Her husband was not able to repair it. So when she heard about the loan process, she came to AFS and requested an individual loan of 50000 Afghani for the term of 12 months to buy all the essential construction materials to repair the house. She is very glad that there is a nice process in Afghanistan for supporting those who are really in need of money.

loans.use: To buy construction materials

loans.name: Faghfor Group

texts.en:
Faghfor is the group leader of the Faghfor group. There are four members in this group. They would each like to borrow money for their businesses. 
 Faghfor and Marey want to take a loan for a baking business in their house and want to buy stock for their business.  M. Amen and Pary Jan want to take a loan for their general store. They all want to see progress in their businesses and to receive a loan to make their business larger. 
They want to say that loans can help them in their businesses. They all thank Kiva for aiding the process of small loans in Afghanistan that help support poor people in this country.

loans.use: To buy stock for their businesses, viz. a bakery and a general store.

loans.name: Siddiqan Sharif Masih Group

texts.en:
My name is Siddiqan and I’ve been a citizen of a mid-size city, Raiwind, Pakistan for the last 39 years. I am an uneducated lady because my parents couldn’t afford my education expenses. I am married to S. M. and he has run a grocery shop in the community for the last 10 years. I have two kids: one son and one daughter, both enrolled in school. I have a decorative embroidery business. I prepare embroidered dresses ordered by my neighbors and earn an income. With the income, I pay off the school fees for my kids. I am applying for a loan to buy groceries for my husband’s grocery shop. 

I am the group leader for four other women from my locality. Rani baji, Shahnaz baji and Ailas baji each want a loan to buy groceries for their grocery shops. Another Rani baji wants a loan to buy a donkey cart for loading. 

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy groceries for grocery shop

loans.name: Bashiran Group

texts.en:
Bashiran baji is the wife of S. M. who has lived in a mid-size city named Raiwind, Pakistan for the last 20 years. Her husband runs a grocery shop in the community. People come to him to buy groceries. Bashiran baji operates a sewing clothes business. She sews clothes to pay the utility bills for her house. She is applying for a loan to buy groceries for her husband’s grocery shop.

She is the group leader for three other women from her locality. Munia baji wants a loan to buy animals (goats & sheep) for her animal-selling business. Parveen baji wants a loan to buy a sewing machine for sewing clothes. Zarina baji wants a loan to buy groceries for her grocery shop.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy groceries for grocery shop

loans.name: Bushran Allah Rakha Masih Group

texts.en:
Bushran baji has been a citizen of a city named Raiwind, Pakistan for the past 15 years. Raiwind city is famous for its shrines. Her husband's name is A. R. M. and he works in a factory on monthly wage. Bushran baji is the mother of three kids: two daughters and one son. All are getting an education from a local school. Bushra baji runs a bangle selling business. She sells bangles in the community and in the bangle shops also. With the profits from this business she renovated her house and admitted her kids into school. She is applying for a loan to buy bangles to expand her bangle selling business.

She is the group leader of four other women from her locality. Nargis baji and Shahnaz baji each want a loan to buy sewing machines for their sewing clothes business. Sharifan baji and Shaheen baji each want a loan to buy animals (goats & sheep) for their animal selling businesses. 

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy bangles to resell

loans.name: Rasool Siddique Masih Group

texts.en:
Rasool Baji is a citizen of a mid-size city named Raiwind in Pakistan. She owns a two-room brick house and has been living in it with her family for 10 years. Her husband, S. M., sells vegetables. He loads a cart with vegetables and takes it to different areas of Raiwind, calling out his products in a loud voice. Rasool Baji helps by arranging the vegetables on the cart in an orderly way so he can name them easily. Rasool Baji is applying for a loan to buy seasonal vegetables for her husband’s vegetable selling business.

Rasool Baji is the group leader of another three women from her locality. Zubaida Baji wants a loan to buy mason's tools. Rani Baji wants a loan to buy a donkey cart for loading. Hanifan Baji wants a loan to buy bangles to resell.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy seasonal vegetables to sell; to buy materials for each group member's business.

loans.name: Abdullah

texts.en:
Abdullah is the son of A. G.. He now lives in district 8th of Kabul, Afghanistan. During the war, Abdullah and his family migrated to Pakistan and subsequently, they returned to Kabul and settled in their own house which had been destroyed during the war. They have tried hard to live in that house in a way because they did not have enough money to repair it well.

Abdullah was informed by one of his friends about the lending process, so he came to AFS and requested an individual loan of 50,000 Afghani for the term of 10 months to repair his house and solve his problems.

loans.use: buying construction materials to repair his house

loans.name: Kalsoom

texts.en: Kalsoom baji is the mother of two sons who work in a factory on a monthly wage. Her husband's name is A. R. and he runs a grocery shop. He utilizes a room of his house for his grocery shop. Kalsoom baji operates a clothes sewing business. She takes orders from her neighbors and relatives, and charges $2 per stitching. Kalsoom baji is applying for a loan to buy groceries for her husband’s grocery shop.

loans.use: To buy groceries to sell in a grocery shop

loans.name: Dawlat

texts.en:
Dawlat is a 21-year-old single man who lives in jalalabad of Ningarhar province, . He is the only breadwinner in a family of eight members. His father was a farmer, but he is now 60 years old and can not working more.

Dawlat graduated from high school last year but was unable to pursue higher education, due to financial problems. His father was very weak, and his family needed someone to support them. Dawlat was brave enough to assume this responsibility and decided to start a small business. He founded a small shop in the city of Jalalabad to sell mobile phones and phone cards. He already had experience in this field, having worked in his friend's shop during his spare time while in school.  

He wants to buy more mobile phone stock for his shop, so he has requested a loan of 50,000 Afghanis from AFSG. He hopes that this loan will bring positive change and benefits to his own and his family members' lives.

loans.use: To buy mobile phones for his shop.

loans.name: Nawidullah

texts.en: Nawidullah M. A. lives in Kabul, Afghanistan's 6th district. He is single and lives with his six-member family. His older brother, who is 30, wants to get married but lacks the money to cover the expenses. He would like to take out an individual loan of 50,000 Afghani ($1,075), with a repayment term of six months, to support his brother. He would like to state that Kiva is an effective process that helps people solve their problems.

loans.use: To cover wedding expenses.

loans.name: Moeung

texts.en:
S. O., 28, is a good mother who cares for her two children in the family home; both of them are still young and attend the local public school. S. owns a medium-size farmland where she grows different kinds of vegetables, such as  tomato, cucumber, morning glory, and cabbage. She can grow two harvests each year. 

S. O. is married to Mr. Nara, 34, who helps her grow the vegetables. They are living in Kompong Cham Province, Cambodia. Each year, the family has to hire a villager's cow to plow their farm because they lack the capital to buy a cow. Therefore, S. O. has requested a loan to purchase a cow so she can raise its offspring. (S. O.'s husband is pictured.)

loans.use: To purchase a cow

loans.name: Nhor

texts.en: Mrs. Nhor L. lives in Ta Daul Bey village in Kandal province. She owns a small restaurant. Her husband, Mr. Mao Van, is a farmer who owns a plot of land where he cultivates rice. They have four children, one of whom is employed in a garment factory while the others are enrolled in the local school. Although they try to work hard, they still earn less income than what they need to provide their children with an education. Mrs. Nhor L. is requesting a loan to support her children in their studying. Her husband is on the right in the photo.

loans.use: To pay school fees

loans.name: Srey

texts.en:
Srey P. is a villager in Kok Romeat village in Kandal province. She is employed in a garment factory. Her husband, Pum Sophorn, is a farmer who owns a small piece of land to cultivate rice.

Aside from the plantation, he owns a loud speaker which he rents for weddings, ceremonies, parties, and so on.

Srey wants to expand her husband’s plantation by purchasing a piece of land to cultivate rice. She hopes to increase her income and improve her family's living conditions with this loan. She has two children, one who attends the local school. The youngest is too young to work or study. Her husband and child are presented with her in the picture.

loans.use: Purchasing land to cultivate rice.

loans.name: Sovang

texts.en:
Sovang M. is 27 years old and she lives in Thmey village, in Kandal province.  She and her husband, Khut Chenda, use rice to make wine.  Since their business is doing well, they want to expand, but they do not have much money. 

Sovang decided to ask for a loan to add to her savings to make more wine to earn income.  She hopes to increase her income and improve their living conditions with this loan.  She has two children who are enrolled in the local school.  Her husband is shown in the photo.

loans.use: Add to savings to make more wine to earn income.

loans.name: Ry

texts.en: Mrs. Ry N. lives in Prachum Angk village in Kandal province. She is a beautician who is hired by people involved in weddings, parties, and so on. Since her career is doing well, she wants to buy more cosmetic supplies to support her business. She is a 28-year-old widow with a child who is attending the local school.

loans.use: To buy more cosmetic supplies to support her business

loans.name: Prum

texts.en:
Prum S. is 38 years old and her husband's name is Sophat, age 41. They currently make a living as local cultivators. They plant different kinds of vegetables. As another revenue source, they are domestic produce traders. The couple has two children who are students in secondary school.

The mature cashew season is coming. To earn additional income, Prum is asking for a loan to order cashews to store in her home, and re-sell to gain income. She lives with her family in Kompong Cham Province.

loans.use: Order cashews.

loans.name: Sann

texts.en:
Sann M. lives in Hang Heng village, in Takeo province.  She is a farmer who owns a plot of land to cultivate rice.  Her husband, Ung Vanna, owns a small business selling coconuts.  Although they try to work hard, they still earn less income than needed to support their family. 

Thus, Sann decided to ask for a loan to buy a cow for breeding, to earn more income.  She is 42 years old and the mother of four children, one of whom is a tailor while the others attend the local school.  Her husband is presented in the picture with her.

loans.use: Buy a cow for breeding to earn more income.

loans.name: Noun

texts.en:
Mrs. Noun N. is a villager in Saen Born village in Takeo province. She is a chicken breeder. Since her business is doing well, she wants to expand it. Thus, she decided to request a loan to purchase more baby chickens for breeding and she would use the rest of money to buy chicken feed for her chicken business. She hopes to increase her income and improve the family living conditions with this loan. Her husband, Mr. Khun Phoeun, is a farmer who owns a piece of land on which he cultivates rice and he also is a coconut seller.

Mrs. Noun N. is a 29-year-old mother of three children, one of whom is attending the local school while the others are too young to work or study. Her husband is presented in the picture with her.

loans.use: To purchase more baby chickens and chicken feed for her business

loans.name: Aun

texts.en:
Aun S. was born in 1965 and now lives in Saen Born village, in Takeo province. She is a Khmer noodle seller. Her husband, Khun Noeun, is a farmer who owns a plot of land to cultivate rice. Aside from this plantation, he is a construction worker.

Although they try to work hard, they still do not earn enough income to support their household. In order to improve their living, Aun decided to ask for a loan to buy a cow and four piglets for breeding, to earn more income.

She has five children, two of whom are construction workers while the others are enrolled in the local school. Her husband is presented in the picture with her.

loans.use: Buy a cow and four piglets for breeding, to earn more income.

loans.name: Pich

texts.en:
Pich S. lives in Prey Meas village, in Takeo province. She is a farmer who owns a plot of land to cultivate rice. Pich is also a pig breeder.

On her land, she faces an obstacle because she usually pays too much money to hire a laborer with two oxen to plow the field. Thus, she decided to ask for a loan to buy two oxen for breeding and to reduce her expense for plowing.

Pich is a 42-year-old mother of three children, one of whom is employed in a garment factory while the others attend the local school.

loans.use: Buy two oxen for breeding and to reduce her expense for plowing.

loans.name: Sa Rorn

texts.en:
Sa Rorn K. lives in Sam Nor Kmao village in Takeo province. She is a farmer who owns a small piece of land to cultivate rice. Her husband, Nhang Chaem, is a construction worker.

Although they try to work hard they still earn less income than needed to support their family. In order to improve the living, Sa decided to request a loan to buy a motorbike for her husband to become a taxi driver to earn more income.

She is 41 years old and the mother of four children, one of whom is a tailor while another is a waiter in a restaurant. One is a construction worker and the youngest is too young to work or study. Her husband is presented on the left of photo.

loans.use: Buy a motorbike for her husband to become motor taxi driver to earn more income.

loans.name: Batbileg

texts.en:
Batbileg N., 54, lives in the Bayanzurh district of Ulaanbaatar, Mongolia, with his wife and three children. His eldest son, Erbold, and daughter, Azjargal, 21, are college students. The youngest daughter stays home and supports her parents' business.

For the last several years, with his wife, he has run a small retail stall selling luggage and handbags, in Narantuul market, the largest open market in Ulaanbaatar. Based on his experience as a retailer, he imports decent quality, cheap luggage and handbags from Beijing, China, and his wife resells them in Narantuul market.

Batbileg and his wife hope to able to finance their eldest son's wedding and pay for their second daughter’s college tuition. They are hard-working, entrepreneurial family. Batbileg, with his wife, requests a loan to improve his luggage and handbag imports from China.

loans.use: Buy luggage and handbags.

loans.name: Savat

texts.en:
Savat K. is a villager in Krang Roung village, in Takeo province. He owns a small business and sells mix ice-cream and grocery goods. Since his business has a lot of consumers, he wants to expand it. Thus, he decided to ask for a loan to purchase more ice-cream and grocery products for his customers.

He hopes to earn more profit and improve his family's living conditions with this loan. His wife, Net Savy, is a Khmer noodle seller. Savat is 35 years old and the father of two children who attend the local school. His wife is shown in the picture with him.

loans.use: Purchase more ice-cream and grocery products for his customers.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Khem

texts.en:
Khem K. H. is 29 years old and a resident of Kompong Cham Province, Cambodia, where she grows rice and vegetable crops.  She collects her mature produce and sells to her buyer four times a year.  She gains income to help meet her family's foods needs.  

She is married with three children who are single and go to school.  Her husband assists her in the farming business.  K. has requested a loan in order to support her business activities.  She will use the loan to buy seeds and to rent a cultivating machine for plowing farmland.

loans.use: Buy seeds and rent a cultivating machine.

loans.name: Chorn

texts.en:
Chorn M. was born in 1950, and he lives in Krang Roung village, in Takeo province. He is a teacher in the local school. His wife, Ung Sovan, is a farmer who owns a plot of land to cultivate rice.

The couple has a child who is a motorbike repairer. Even though Chorn’s family members have different careers, they still earn less income than needed to provide a better house for their family.

Chorn decided to ask for a loan to add to his savings to buy sand, cement, and the other construction supplies to build a house for his family. His wife is shown in the picture with him.

loans.use: Buy supplies to build a house for his family.

loans.name: Savorn

texts.en: Mrs. Savorn U. is a farmer in Krang RoU. Village in Takeo Province. She owns a small piece of land to cultivate rice. She is a 53-year-old widow with three children, two of whom are employed in a garment factory while the other is a soldier. Even though they all have careers, they still don’t earn enough to improve their standard of living. Mrs. Savorn U. is requesting a loan to supplement money she’s already saved so she can buy a motorbike for her third child to drive to work.

loans.use: Purchase a motorbike for her third child to drive to work.

loans.name: Noeurn

texts.en:
Mrs. Noeurn N. lives in Seirey Douch Village in Takeo Province. She is a farmer who owns a plot of land to cultivate rice. She also breeds pigs. She is a 56 year old widow with three children; two of them own a small restaurant where they sell rice, soup, Chinese noodle, coffee, soft drink, etc., and the third helps out with the plantation. 

She is applying for a loan which she will combine with her savings to buy an “electric cow” (a machine that pulls a plow and runs on fuel) for her third child. The electric cow will be used to plow the field and transport rice products. Mrs. Noeurn N. hopes to increase her income and improve her family’s living conditions as a result of this loan.

loans.use: Add to her savings to buy an electric cow for her third child.

loans.name: Sokhorn

texts.en: Mrs. Sokhorn N. is a villager in Dork Por village in Takeo province. She is a coconut seller. Since her business is doing well, she wants to expand it. Thus, she decided to ask for a loan to buy more coconuts and a cart to transport them. She hopes to increase her income and improve her family's living conditions. Her husband, Mr. May Pouk, is a farmer who owns a plot of land used to cultivate rice. Mrs. Sokhorn N. is 36 years old and the mother of three children; one is employed in a garment factory, one attends the local school and the youngest one is too young to work or study. Her husband appears on the right in the photo.

loans.use: To buy coconuts and a cart to transport them.

loans.name: Khy

texts.en:
Khy S., 37, is a villager living in Phnom Penh City. She is the mother of three children who go to the local school.

Her husband, Noeun, is 37 year old, who works as a local building worker for a company. She makes a living selling Khmer noodle in the small store front of her home. She can generate a daily income of $4 to support her family. Most of her clients are neighbors who living near her house.

To make extra income, Khy is applying for an $800 loan to purchase a trailer-motor, so she can transport vegetables to sell at the market. With the extra income, they will attain a higher standard of living.

loans.use: Purchase a trailer-motor.

loans.name: Mom

texts.en: Mrs. Mom O. is 49 years old and she lives in Sophy village in Takeo province. She is a pig breeder. Her husband, Mr. Sum Chab, is a farmer who owns a plot of land to cultivate rice. He also is a palm juice collector. Mrs. Mom O. is requesting a loan to buy a cow for breeding to earn more income. She is 49 years old and the mother of five children, one of whom is employed in a garment factory while the other three are enrolled in the local school and the remaining is too young to work or study. Her husband is shown on the left of photo.

loans.use: To buy a cow for breeding.

loans.name: Phall

texts.en: Mrs. Phall S. is 32 years old and she lives in Seirey Douch village in Takeo province. She is a farmer who owns a piece of land to cultivate rice. Aside from this plantation, she and her husband, Mr. Him Run, are fish sellers in the local market. In their business, they face an obstacle because they do not have their own motorbike to go to buy fish from the other people to resell; thus, they pay too much money for motor taxi to transport their goods. In order to deal with this problem, Mrs. Phall S. decided to ask for a loan to add to her savings to buy a motorbike for her business to be easier. She has a child who is attending the local school. Her husband is in the picture with her.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike to make her business easier.

loans.name: Saren

texts.en: Mrs. Saren N. is 40 years old and she lives in Chi Chrab village in Takeo province. She is a pig breeder. Her husband, Mr. Pet Nat, is a farmer who owns a piece of land to cultivate rice. This couple has five children, two of whom are employed while the others are attending the local school. Mrs. Saren N. needs a loan to add to her savings to buy a motorbike for her child to drive to work. Her husband is shown in the picture with her.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike for her child to drive to work.

loans.name: Ro

texts.en: Mr. Ro P. lives in Svay Run village in Takeo province. He is a motor taxi driver and his wife, Mrs. Nou Khorn, is a farmer who grows rice on their own a plot of land.  They do not earn enough income to build a better house for their family.  Mr. Ro P. requests a loan to buy cement and other construction supplies, and to hire laborers to build the house. He is a 51-year-old father of six children, two of whom are employed while the other four attend the local school. He and his wife are pictured.

loans.use: To buy cement and other construction supplies, and to hire laborers to build a new house for his family.

loans.name: Nhor

texts.en: Mrs. Nhor N. was born in 1951 and she lives in Krang Roung village in Takeo province. Currently she is a farmer who grows rice on her own piece of land. Her husband, Mr. Khat Choeun, is a recycling middleman. His business is doing well, so he wants to expand it. In order to help her husband grow his business, Mrs. Nhor N. requests a loan to combine with her savings to buy a motorbike.  Then she can drive to buy more recyclables to resell. She hopes to increase her income to help improve life for her family. She has two children, one of whom is employed in a garment factory while the other is employed in a company. She and her husband are pictured.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike for driving to buy more recyclables to resell

loans.name: Andrea

texts.en: Andrea C. is a 48-year-old mother of four. She sells fish and sometimes catches bangus fry (milkfish) to support the needs of her family. Her income, together with her husband’s irregular income from driving a tricycle (motorcycle with side car, pictured), is not enough to expand her business. She applied for this loan to buy a motorcycle and to help grow her fish vending business. She would like to get a stall in the market so she can sell higher volumes of fish. With more income, she hopes to save enough money to build another tricycle for her son to drive. She also hopes to send her children to university, and dreams of having a better house.

loans.use: To buy a motorcycle and to help grow her fish vending business.

loans.name: Hout

texts.en: Hout Chantha, pictured here, is 44 and the good mother of four children who are single; two of them are employed and the other two still go to school. She is a domestic rice trader; she orders rice from farmers to stock in her home and re-sells it to gain income. To help feed the family, her husband works as a construction foreman for a company. Because rice is Chantha's main source to make an income for her family, she would like to request a loan of $1000 as capital to order more rice to sell. Chantha and her family live in Phnom Penh City, in Cambodia.

loans.use: To order more rice to sell

loans.name: Josephine
