texts.en: Mrs. Josephine O. is 54 years old and married to her husband Jaime, who is a driver.  She is blessed with two children who both got married. Josephine is a good member of the cooperative and she pays her obligations religiously. Her project is snack vending and this project is still progressing. She borrowed from Paglaum MPC the amount of PHP 20,000 to be used for additional capitalization of her projects. Aside from being a snack vendor she uses her extra time to cook at a restaurant as an additional source of income. Her hopes and aspirations are to improve her family members’ lives and live happily forever.

loans.use: To buy ingredients for snacks and empanadas

loans.name: Jovy

texts.en: Having a mini "carenderia" (small restaurant) is really a big help for Mrs. Jovy P..  She is 35 years old, married, and lives at Poblacion, Panaon, Misamis Occidental. She has two children. Her husband is a motorcycle driver. Considering the economic crisis we are facing today, Mrs. P. works very hard cooking in her carenderia in order to earn the money her family needs to survive. Fortunately, the daily consumption needs of her family are met because of the carenderia. Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative is a big help to her family and business. She has availed loans several times. Now, she applies for PHP 7,000 to buy additional meats, fishes, and spices for her carenderia. She hopes that her business will be successful and expand into a full restaurant someday, where she can sell a variety of foods.

loans.use: To buy meats, fishes, and spices for carenderia

loans.name: Bonifacia

texts.en: Mrs. D. is a resident of Capundag, Sapang Dalaga, Mis. Occ. She operates a "ukay-ukay" (used clothing) business located at Poblacion, Sapang Dalaga, Misamis Occidental. She’s 47 years old, married, and has four children, all of whom are working. Her husband is a farmer but also helps manage their business. Her children gave them the capital to open a used clothing retail business. She’s planning to expand the business but she lacks capital. When she became a member of Paglaum, she readily took a loan for her 1st cycle. She’s now on her 2nd cycle and is requesting a loan of PHP 5,000.00 to buy additional bundles of used clothing. Her hope and aspiration is that her business will expand and become stable in the future and provide a decent life for the family.

loans.use: To purchase additional bundles of used clothing

loans.name: Zalve

texts.en: Zalve B. is 30 years old, married and a resident of Calaran, Calamba, Misamis Occidental. She has two children; one is in school. The couple is engaged in farming and hog raising. She became a member and used the credit services. Her loan as of now is Php 14,900.00 to purchase fertilizer for her cornfields and to purchase piglets. The couple is hoping that they will always have a good harvest and her hog-raising project will expand and grow in the future.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer and piglets

loans.name: Hoa

texts.en: Hoa K., 27, is married with two young children and lives with her husband in Prey Veng province. She stays at home doing housework and cooking for her family members. Her husband has operated a taxi business for over six years and he is able to make a profit of US$10 every day. Hoa K. is asking for a loan to replace an old and unreliable taxi for her husband. (Hoa K. is pictured with her husband and two young children.)

loans.use: To replace taxi.

loans.name: Merlinda

texts.en:
Merlinda T. is a 49 year-old mother of six.  She raises pigs and carabao in order to support her husband, who is farming a small parcel of land. Merlinda’s previous loans in ASHI (Ahon Sa Hirap, Incorporated) impacted her life and her family. She sends some of her children to school out of her profits.

She is applying for this loan to buy and sell livestock and feed. She wants to venture into this kind of business in order to increase her income and support the needs of the family.

She hopes that in the future their business will run smoothly and she can get a stall in the market. She dreams of sending her remaining two children to college so they can land a decent job.

loans.use: To buy and sell livestock and feed.

loans.name: Deab

texts.en: Deab S., 56, is a widow who lives in Phnom Penh, Cambodia. She has six children and has a business selling rice and food from her home. She and her daughter sell rice and typically make US$3 of profit per day. She is also supported by four children, two working as construction workers and two others as garment factory workers. Deab S. is asking for a loan to reinvest in her business. (Deab S. was not available so her daughter is pictured instead, on the right hand side.)

loans.use: Reinvest in her business (selling rice).

loans.name: Mohammad Abrahim

texts.en:
The man who is pictured is Mohammad Abrahim, the son of A. W.. He lives in Kabul, Afghanistan. He is 45 years old and is married with four children. He lives with his family of 8, including his father and mother, because he is the oldest member of his family and the responsibility of taking care of his old father and mother is on him.

He needs to build two more rooms in his house because the house is very small and by building two new rooms he can have enough space. He wants to receive an individual loan of 50000 Afghani for the term of 10 months. Consequently, he appreciates this process of loan-making in Afghanistan.

loans.use: To buy construction materials

loans.name: Pen

texts.en: Pen S. is a 66-year-old widow with six children and resides in Phnom Penh, Cambodia. She sells fruit and typically earns US$3 profit per day. She is also supported by three children working in construction. Pen S. would like to take out a loan of US$1200 to reinvest in her fruit stand.

loans.use: To purchase fruit to sell

loans.name: Sorn

texts.en: Sorn K. is 42 years old and sells palm sugar in Takeo province. His business has been around for about twenty years and he makes US$100 every month. His wife, Nhem Chanthoeun, 41, pictured here, is a vegetable seller in the market, and she is able to make US$20 in revenue per day. Sorn K. is asking for a loan of US$1000 to purchase palm sugar to sell. He sees this investment as an opportunity to increase his daily income.

loans.use: To purchase palm sugar to sell.

loans.name: Habibar Rahman Group

texts.en: H. R. is the group leader of H. R. group. There are five members in this group. Each of them would like to take out a loan for their own business, for a total amount for their group of 50,000 Afghani. H. R. and Rahela want to take out loans for tailoring businesses. Tamana and Kamala will use their loans for their brother’s general store, and Shafeq Ahmad wants the loan for his bookstore. All of them want to expand and grow their businesses.  With the money they receive, they are confident they can make a good profit and run their businesses in a good way. They are happy about the loan process and want to say to Kiva lenders that it will support the entrepreneurs a lot.

loans.use: To expand and grow their businesses.

loans.name: Chan

texts.en:
Mrs. Chan K. lives in Hang Heng village in Takeo province. She is a farmer and owns a piece of land to cultivate rice. Her husband, Mr. Bou Khim, is a construction worker. His workplace is far from the house, so he usually drives the motorbike to work.

He now wants to change his old motorbike because it is so old and difficult to drive to work. Thus, Mrs. Chan K. requests a loan to purchase a different motorbike for her husband. She is a 39-year-old mother of three children; one is employed in a garment factory, and the others are attending the local school.

loans.use: Purchase a different motorbike for personal use

loans.name: Sayed Temor Shah

texts.en: This is S. Temor Shah the son of S. A.. He lives in the 8th district in Kabul, Afghanistan. He is 40, married, and has 5 children. After emiigrating from Peshawar, Pakistan, he lived in a rental house with family members. Recently, he purchased a piece of land and decided to build it. So he went to AFS and requested an individual loan of $1075 (50000 AFN) for the term of 10 months. With the loan and the money he saved, he wants to purchase construction supplies. He hopes to build his house as soon as possible. He wants to mention that Kiva lenders are the best.

loans.use: Purchase construction materials to build a house

loans.name: Mrs. Sam Ross Um  Village Bank Group

texts.en: Nineteen people who live in DaeU. Doung village in Takeo province make up the village bank loan. All the members plan to use their loans for different purposes. Mrs. Sam Ross U. is the village bank president, who has been selected by the members. She is a farmer who owns a plot of land to cultivate rice. She is also a rice middle woman, and a fruit-seller in the local market. Both of her businesses are doing well, so she wants to expand them buy purchasing more rice and fruit to resell to earn more profit to support her family. Her husband, Mr. Muth Chek, is a motor-taxi driver. Mrs. Sam Ross U. is 39 years old and the mother of 4 children, who attend the local school. (Mrs. PU. C.'s husband is in the picture.)

loans.use: Purchase more rice and fruit to resell

loans.name: Meach

texts.en: Meach K. is 48 years old and has a business selling chickens and ducks at the market. She earns approximately $7.50 profit per day. She is a widow who lives with three children. She is also supported by one child who works as construction worker. Meach K. requests a loan to purchase chickens and ducks to sell at the market.

loans.use: Purchase chickens and ducks to sell

loans.name: Soy

texts.en: Soy S. A., 38, is a widow with three young children living at home in the Takeo province. She makes collars, and typically earns $6 each day. She receives help from two children who are construction workers. Soy S. A. requests a loan of $400 to purchase materials to make collars.

loans.use: Purchase materials to make collars

loans.name: Thouk

texts.en: Thouk C., 31, is married, has two children, and resides in the Takeo province. She weaves silk scarves and makes $8.00 every day. Her husband is a motor-taxi driver and typically earns $10.00 per day. Two of their children are in school. Thouk C. requests a loan to purchase land, so she and her husband can become farmers to supplement their income to support the family.

loans.use: Purchase land to farm

loans.name: Hin

texts.en:
Hin P., 34, is a professional weaver, making $2 each day, in the Takeo province. She is married and has three children living at home, that she supports.

Her husband, Soeun Bol, makes approximately $6 every day as a construction worker. The economic downturn has made construction in Cambodia pretty slow and usually he has no work to do.

Hin would like a loan of $1200. She will purchase wood and carpentry tools for her husband to start a carpentry business. Before doing construction, her husband was a carpenter. Hin P. (right) is pictured with her husband.

loans.use: Purchase wood and carpentry tools.

loans.name: Pov

texts.en:
Pov K. is 25 years old and has a business making and selling mats in the TaK. province. She has been operating this business since 2006 and is able to earn about $10 every day. Her husband sells mosquito nets and makes approximately $10 per day. The couple has two young children.

Pov would like to take out a loan of $700 to purchase mats, mosquito nets and other materials to sell. Pov K. (right) is pictured with her husband and their young child.

loans.use: Purchase mats, mosquito nets and other materials to sell.

loans.name: Touch

texts.en:
Touch P., 46, is married and lives with her husband in the Takeo province. She works in a grocery store in front of a garment factory, near her house to earn a living. She makes $20 in revenue every day. Her husband grows and sells trees, and he makes $3 a day.

This couple has three children and all of them are in school. Touch is asking for loan to expand her grocery store by adding more items to sell to meet her client’s demand. Touch P. (right) is pictured with her husband.

loans.use: Purchase items to expand her grocery store.

loans.name: Borhanudin

texts.en: Borhanudin is the son of F.. He lives in the 6th district of Kabul, Afghanistan, with his six-member family. He wants to repair his house to be able to live comfortably. He has requested an individual loan of 50000 afghani for the term of 12 months to buy construction materials. He is happy that through the loan process one can solve his/her problems.

loans.use: buying construction materials

loans.name: Pheng's Group

texts.en: S. B. is 36 years old and is the leader of a group of three borrowers. He is the father of two children, both of whom are married and live separately from him. He is married to Chanseng, who is 29 years old and is a garment worker. S. B. is a blacksmith for the whole commune, which allows him to earn up to $5 per day. Whenever a house is built, the family who owns it always calls him to fix the doors, windows, and fence. He is taking a loan to buy hundreds of kilos of metal for his business.  The other group members are Y., a local farmer who is 60 years old and taking a loan to buy a door, and S., another local farmer who is 49 years old and applying for a loan to redecorate her house. They all live in Phnom Penh, Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy metal for his business

loans.name: Susan

texts.en:
Susan I. is currently in the business of selling beer at home and is requesting a loan to open a bar. Susan is 30 years old and is married to a businessman. She has three children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a house.


BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To open a bar

loans.name: Juan

texts.en:
Juan E. is currently in the business of selling beans at the market and is requesting a loan to open up a shop. Juan is 39 years old and is married to a businessman. She has four children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay school fees for her children.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To open a shop

loans.name: Gnon's Group

texts.en: K. is fifty-five years old, the leader of a group of three, and the mother of seven children. Four of them are married and live separately, one is employed as a local construction worker, and the other two are students. She is married to Heng, age fifty-two, who is a local farmer. K. is also a farmer which she has learned from her parents since 1979. She is a good manager and a responsible neighbor. Not only does she work at farming, she also wants to work at fishing. K. is asking for a loan to buy a small fishing boat for her fishing. The other members of the group are B., who is twenty-nine years old and a local construction foreman, and who is looking for a loan to buy a generator for his work, and also B., age twenty-eight, a local construction worker who wants a loan to buy groceries for his wife to sell. They all live in Phnom Penh.

loans.use: To buy a small fishing boat for her fishing

loans.name: Gul Hara

texts.en: Gul Hara is the daughter of N.. She lives in district six in Kabul, Afghanistan. She is married with six children. Gul Hara is fully responsible for taking care of the family. She is a seamstress and sews different kinds of pillows. She requested an individual loan of $1075 for the term of ten months to buy the materials needed for her sewing so she can increase her business. She is very thankful to the Kiva leaders.

loans.use: for buying needed materials

loans.name: Mary

texts.en: Mary is 49 years old and married with seven children. She sells provisions and drinks to her customers. She hopes for a loan in the amount of N100,000 to purchase more provisions and drinks to sell. She hopes to expand this business. She is indeed grateful to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more provisions and drinks to sell

loans.name: Mrs. Kunthea Chheng Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Kunthea C. is the village bank leader for eleven people who all live in Mkak village in Takeo province.  All the members will use the loan for different purposes. She is a fruit seller in the local market. Her husband, Mr. Neth Vy, is a motor taxi driver. Kunthea is requesting a loan to bU. more fruit to resell and to fix her husband’s motorbike. She would use the rest of the money to bU. piglets to start a pig breeding business in order to earn more income to support her family. She is twenty-eight years old and the mother of two children who are too young to work or study. Mr. Veasna U. is shown in the picture instead of his wife who is a member of the group.

This is a village bank loan consisting mainly of end-of-term loans. Four members have end-of-term loans and the rest have monthly payment loans. These members are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMK’s main product because it is the most beneficial to Cambodia’s poor. It allows them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able. Most clients start to make payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK’s clients make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and AMK has a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: Buy fruit to resell, fix her husband’s motorbike, and buy piglets to start pig breeding business.

loans.name: Pana Group

texts.en: Farida is the group leader of Pana group. There are two members in this group and each of them needs a loan to expand her business. Farida wants to take out a loan for her husband who has a fruit cart. Faiz Khnum wants to take out a loan for her embroidery business. They want a loan of $600 for the term of ten months. They like this process because it can support one to expand and progress in business.

loans.use: for expanding business

loans.name: Ijeoma

texts.en: Ijeoma sells electrical materials like wire, bulbs, etc. She is 35 years old and married with four children. She hopes for a loan in the amount of N50,000 to purchase more electrical materials to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more electrical materials to sell

loans.name: Esohe

texts.en: Esohe is 44 years old and married with four children. She lives in Benin city, Edo state, Nigeria. She sells cooked foods and drinks. She hopes for a loan in the amount of N100,000 to purchase more foodstuffs to cook and sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs to cook and sell

loans.name: Mrs. Sa Rorn Sin Village Bank Group

texts.en: Seventeen people who live in Daeum Doung village in Takeo province make up this village bank group and all the members will use the loan for different purposes. Mrs. Sa Rorn S. was selected to be the village bank president by the members. She is a farmer who owns a small piece of land for cultivating rice. Her husband, Mr. Chin Khum, is a fruit seller. Since his business is doing well, he wants to expand it and he needs a motorbike to transport the fruit to sell. Mrs. Sa Rorn S. decided to ask for a loan to add to her savings to bU. a motorbike for her husband’s business. She is twenty-seven years old with two children who are five years old and four months old.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike for her husband’s business.

loans.name: Adesuwa

texts.en: Adesuwa sells clothes and she is also a tailor. She sews lovely clothes for her customers. She hopes for a loan in the amount of N100,000 to purchase more clothes to sell. She is 39 years old and married with a child. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more clothes to sell

loans.name: Keji

texts.en:
Keji H. is currently in the business of selling groundnut paste and is requesting a loan to buy a grinding mill for the business.  Keji, 22 and married to a nurse, has two children, both attending school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay their school fees.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  

In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To buy a grinding mill for the business.

loans.name: Jenifa

texts.en:
Jenifa T. is 40 years old and is married with a husband who is a businessman. She has three children and her children go to school.

Jenifa is currently in the business of selling onions and is requesting a loan to buy more onions and cooking oil to sell. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a house for rent.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To buy more onions and cooking oil to sell

loans.name: Chhoem

texts.en:
M. is 38 years old and a resident of Pursat Province. She is a mother of two children who are students. She is married to Huot, 47, who sells charcoal across the commune. 

M. earns a living selling vegetables in the market and has done so since 1999. She needs to travel to some parts of the commune in order to buy the vegetables in bulk. She hires a motorbike for her transportation. She is applying for a loan of $600 to buy a motorbike for her business transportation. M. dreams that her children will earn their degrees.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike for her business transportation.

loans.name: Theresa

texts.en: Theresa sells drinks. She is 42 years old and married with 2 children. She has been in this business since 2004. She lives in Asaba, Delta State, Nigeria. She needs the loan amount of N120,000 to purchase more drinks to sell. She says thanks to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more drinks to sell

loans.name: Beatrice

texts.en: Beatrice sells cooked foods like rice and beans, etc. She lives in Asaba, Delta, Nigeria. She hopes for the loan amount of N80,000 to purchase more foodstuffs to cook and sell to her customers. She is 42 years old and married with 4 children. She says thanks to all that make this loan possible.

loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs to cook and sell

loans.name: Cynthia

texts.en: Cynthia sells and rents VCDs to her customers. She started this business in 2001. She hopes for the loan amount of N80,000 to purchase more VCDs to sell and rent to her customers. She hopes to expand this business. She is 30 years old and married with 3 childern. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more VCDs to rent and sell

loans.name: Judith

texts.en: Judith is 28 years old. She sells cooked food and drinks. She is married with 3 children, and she lives in Asaba, Delta State, Nigeria. She wants to satisfy the demand of her customers by requesting the loan amount of N100,000 to purchase more foodstuffs and drinks to sell and cook. She says thanks to all who make this possible.

loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs and drinks to cook and sell

loans.name: Nyamdorj

texts.en: Nyamdorj D. is 31, married and father of one child. In 2002, he began to run a wholesale business. He buys slaughtered livestock from Dundgobi, one of the southern provinces of Mongolia, and resells them at an outdoor meat market in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. Nyamdorj has a minibus that he used to use for transporting the animals. With his business profit, he has been able to build a house. Together with his wife, Nyamdulam, he plans to buy a condo in downtown Ulaanbaatar and save money for his child's future tuition. With this loan, he will buy a second-hand but better minibus for his business.

loans.use: To buy a minibus

loans.name: Rat

texts.en:
R., 65, is a mother of two children; one is married and lives separately and one is single and helps the family work. She is married to Keo, 66, who works as a local farmer on the land behind his house. 

R. is a local farmer who plants rice and vegetables on the land that she derived from her parents. Besides paying the family's expenses she also has to hire the neighbor's buffalo for her farming. R. is asking for a loan of $1200 to buy a pair of buffalo for her farming and to renovate her house. She wants to buy a pumping machine.

loans.use: To buy a pair of buffalo for her farming and to renovate her house.

loans.name: Judith

texts.en: Judith is 32 years old and married with a child. She sells provisions and cosmetics. She has been in this business since 2004. She needs the loan amount of N100,000 to purchase more provisions and cosmetics to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more provisions and cosmetics to sell

loans.name: Narantsetseg

texts.en: Narantsetseg T. lives with her husband and her youngest son in the Bayanzurh district of Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. She runs a small retail business for organ meat and the heads of livestock. Her husband and son work in construction as contractors. She has been running a retail business for the last nine years. The business has been doing pretty well and with its profits, she has been able to pay for her three children's weddings. She dreams one day of having her own vegetable garden next to her home. She is requesting a loan for purchasing more organs and heads before the price of wholesale meat products goes up in the spring.

loans.use: To buy more organs and animal heads

loans.name: Tina

texts.en: Tina sells cooked foods and drinks. She started this business in 2004. She hopes for the loan amount of N80,000 to purchase more drinks and foodstuffs to cook and sell. She is 40 years old and married with 3 children. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders for their financial support.

loans.use: To purchase more drinks and foodstuffs to cook and sell

loans.name: Ifeayichukwu

texts.en: Ifeayichukwu is 26 years old and married. She sells provisions and drinks. She lives in Asaba, Delta State, Nigeria. She is requesting a loan of N 100,000 to purchase more provisions and drinks to sell. She is a LAPO client. She says thank you to all who make this loan possible.

loans.use: To purchase more provisions and drinks to sell

loans.name: Augustina

texts.en: Augustina is 31 years old and married with three children. She sells provisions and VCDs to her customers. She hopes to expand this business. She is requesting a loan of N 80,000 to purchase more provisions and VCDs to sell. She is a LAPO client. She thanks Kiva lenders and LAPO for their financial support.

loans.use: To purchase more provisions and VCDs to sell

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary M. is currently in the business of selling onions at home and is requesting a loan to buy a motorbike to transport onions to the market. Mary is 45 years old and is married to a policeman. She has six children who are attending school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a shop at the market.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: buy a motorbike to transport onions to the market

loans.name: Enhtuya

texts.en:
Enhtuya B., 37, is a married mother with two children. Her family used to live in Tuv province, in central Mongolia. In 2005, they moved to Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia, to find a better life.

Together with her husband Byambasuren, she runs a retail business in their yard. She buys old and broken trailers that hitch to Soviet-style pickup trucks, and her husband repairs and resells them. These are used often to transport a variety of goods between provinces.

They pay 1.5-2.5 million tugrigs (1,500 tugrigs=$1 USD) per broken trailer, and then repair them with new tires and other modifications. The fixed-up trailers fetch 5-7 million tugrigs. Repairing one trailer takes around 2-3 months. With their profits, Enhtuya and her husband built their own summer house last year. In the future, she would like to insulate her house better against the harsh Mongolian winter. With her Kiva loan, Enhtuya plans to buy more tires and other spare parts for her business.

loans.use: Buy tires and spare parts to repair trailers to resell

loans.name: Chibuzor

texts.en: Chibuzor is 26 years old and single. He sells groceries and drinks. He has been in this business for the past 4 years. He requests a loan for 150,000 NGN ($1025) to purchase more groceries and drinks to sell. He is a LAPO client. He says thanks to all those who make this loan possible.

loans.use: Purchase more groceries and drinks to sell

loans.name: Ozulonye

texts.en: Ozulonye sells crates of drinks. She started this business in 2000. She requests a loan for 80,000 NGN ($550) to purchase more crates of drinks to sell. She is 28 years old, married, and has 3 children. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders for their financial support.

loans.use: Purchase more crates of drinks to sell

loans.name: Long

texts.en:
S. is 28 years old and a resident of Pursat Province, Cambodia. She is the mother of two children who are students. She is married to Kimleang, 26. The family owns a laborious business. Kimleang produces marble statues and S. sells the marble statues from her house, where everyone knows the statues are sold.

S. is asking for a loan of $1200 to buy more marble and to repair the generator machine. She wants her children to earn their degrees. S. was available during the photograph so her husband is taken instead.

loans.use: To buy more marble to make statues and to repair the generator machine.

loans.name: Lhagvasuren

texts.en:
Lhagvasuren A. is a widow. She has two daughters. Her family lives in Uvurhangay province, one of the Mongolia's southern provinces. Her two daughters are both college students in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia.

She has been running a small restaurant out of a traditional "ger" (a circular, nomadic tent) in Uvurhangay since 1998. She caters mostly to those traveling by car. In her 11 years of service, she has gained significant experience and has some loyal customers. She hopes to be able to afford the yearly college tuition for her two daughters until they graduate. In the future, she dreams of having her own full-service restaurant in the province. She requests a loan to purchase inventory, such as soft drinks, for her business.

loans.use: Buy supplies, such as soft drinks, for restaurant

loans.name: Segerina

texts.en:
Segerina P. is currently in the business of selling beer at home and is requesting a loan to open up a bar at the market.

Segerina is 49 years old and is married with a husband that is a security guard. She has three children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay school fees for her children.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To open up a bar at the market

loans.name: Pamela

texts.en: Pamela is 32 years old and married with a child. She sells shoes and bags. She lives in Delta State, Nigeria. She is requesting the loan amount of N 100,000 to purchase more shoes and bags to sell. She is a LAPO (Lift Above Poverty Organization) client. She says thanks to all that made this loan possible.

loans.use: To purchase more shoes and bags to sell

loans.name: Undrahbayar

texts.en:
Undrahbayar C. lives with her husband and three teenage children who attend the local high school in UvUrhangay, one of Mongolia's southern provinces.  In 2004, she and her husband rented a small stall in the local market and started a retail business in second-hand clothes, purchasing the clothes from wholesalers who import them from South Korea. They started the business with 50,000 MNT ($1 USD=1,500 MNT) and since then, the business capital has increased to 4,300,000 MNT. 

In 2007, because of their business' growth, they rented one more stall to sell the clothes, their dream being to afford a college education for each of their children. Undrahbayar is now requesting a loan to buy more second-hand clothes for her two stalls at the local market.

loans.use: To buy more used clothes for the business.

loans.name: Nancy

texts.en:
Nancy V., 45 years old, is married to Felino, a farmer. They have one child who has finished his studies but doesn't have a stable job yet.

Nancy planned to have plenty of stock for her sari-sari store but she lacks capital. When she became a member of PMPC, she had already availed herself of her 1st cycle loan. Now she has applied for her 8th cycle loan amounting to PHP 20,000 for her to buy additional inventory. Her husband's income from gardening and rice field cultivation help her a lot to support the needs of their family. Her hope and aspiration is that her business will continue to progress and be stable in the future and that there will be a decent life for the family.

loans.use: To purchase groceries for her sari-sari store

loans.name: Tungalagtuya

texts.en:
Tungalagtuya B. lives with her husband and three children in the Bayanzurh district of Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. Their oldest son is a police officer at a local railway police station. Their oldest daughter is a student at a university and their youngest son is a fourth-grade student in a district high school.

In 2002, Tungalagtuya started running a small retail stall for handbags and women's apparel in the Hohburd market, one of the large markets in Ulaanbaatar. However, she was not making a stable profit in the Hohburd market and thus decided to move her business elsewhere. It has been about a year since she moved to the Norjin retail center. Her profits have been much better and her capital has increased since the move.

In the near future, Tungalagtuya would like to diversify her inventory and expand her stall space. Since the spring has just arrived, she requests a loan to purchase spring apparel from Beijing, China (it is very common for Mongolian small retailers to go to Beijing to purchase cheap apparel). In the future, she hopes to be able to buy a small house for her eldest son.

loans.use: To purchase spring apparel for resale

loans.name: Theresa

texts.en: Theresa started a business selling clothes such as shirts and suits in 2005. She is now requesting a loan  of N100,000 to purchase more clothes to sell. Theresa is 54 years old and married with six children. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more clothes to sell.

loans.name: Veronica

texts.en:
Veronica K. is currently in the business of selling green vegetables and is requesting a loan to open up a shop.  Forty-five years old and married to a businessman, Veronica has four children, all attending school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay their school fees. 

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  

In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To open up a shop.

loans.name: Chinyere

texts.en: Chinyere, 41 years old and married with four children, has a poultry farm where she raises birds to sell. In this business for a long time, she is now requesting a loan amount of N100,000 to purchase more poultry to sell. She thanks all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more poultry to sell

loans.name: Dariymaa

texts.en:
Dariymaa B. moved in 2005 with her entire family - including her sister, brother-in-law, nieces and parents - from Uvs province in western Mongolia to the Bayanzurh district of Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. The family sought a better life.

After the move, Dariymaa started a small retail shop selling engines for Korean cars in the Ogoomor market, one of the large outside markets in Ulaanbaatar. In 2006, she bought her first large container to keep her inventory at the market (it is common for retail stall owners here to use cargo containers as makeshift warehouses, and even stores). As her business expanded, she bought her second container in 2008. She purchases engines from wholesalers who import them from Korea and resells them at the Ogoomor market for retail prices. Since the inception of her business, she has gained significant experience in the business.

As the business profit allows, she hopes to one day be able to build a small house on her parents' land. She requests a loan to purchase more engines as the season for a yearly state car inspection approaches.

loans.use: To buy Korean car engines

loans.name: Gladys

texts.en: Gladys, 42 years old and married with two children, rears and sells birds.  Residing in Delta State, Nigeria, she has been in this business for many years and is requesting the loan amount of N100,000 to purchase more birds to sell. She says thanks to all who make this loan possible.

loans.use: To purchase more birds to sell.

loans.name: Chimeddulam

texts.en:
Chimeddulam O. is the widowed mother of two living in Uvurhanghay, one of the southern provinces of Mongolia. Since 2000, she has been operating a retail business from a cargo container she owns that serves as a makeshift warehouse/store in Uugan, the biggest outdoor market in her area. She goes to Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia, to buy car supplies, reselling them to local vehicle owners through her store. 

When she started her retail business, her working capital was 1 million Mongolian tugrigs (1,500 MNT=$1 USD). Now, it has increased to twice that amount. With her business profits, she has paid for her youngest son's college tuition, and with this loan, she will buy more car supplies to increase her business inventory.

loans.use: To buy auto parts for the business.

loans.name: Gabriela

texts.en:
Mrs. Gabriela B. is a resident of Biasong, Misamis, Occidental and has been a member of Paglaum MPC under its microfinance program at Golden Pot Center since 2004. Mrs. B. is a member in good standing and has experienced more than ten loan cycles.

Mrs. B.’s business started with PHP 3,000 capital for a sari-sari store. She managed her business well. Recently, she applied for a loan of PHP 20,000 to buy additional sacks of rice for her store because as she is a licensed NFA rice retailer. She dreams of renovating her store into a concrete one.

loans.use: To buy additional sacks of rice for her sari-sari store

loans.name: Leonita

texts.en:
Leonita C., 29 years old, is the mother of three children and a helpful wife to her husband. Leonita and her family resides at Sta. Cruz, Plaridel, Misamis Occidental.

Leonita helps her husband in their lumber/timber business. They need additional capital amounting to PHP 10,000 to sustain the demand and for Leonita and her husband to be able to grow their business.

loans.use: To finance their timber/lumber business

loans.name: Purevsuren

texts.en:
Purevsuren D. lives with his wife and two children in the Chingeltei district of Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. His wife takes care of their two infant children at home.

Purevsuren makes various types of wooden furniture, including beds, chairs and tables. Although he was trained as a tractor driver, he has a talent for carpentry. Using this ability, he has been running a small carpentry shop for the last dozen years. During these years, he was able to equip his shop with many of the necessary tools.

Today, Purevsuren’s business capital is close to 2,700,000 MNT ($1 USD is approximately MNT 1,500) and he sells 1,500,000 MNT worth of products in a month. He hopes one day to open a carpentry company with his own employees. Purevsuren is a humble and responsible person. He requests a loan to purchase lumber for his carpentry shop.

loans.use: To buy lumber for his carpentry shop

loans.name: Doljinsuren

texts.en:
Doljinsuren D. is a widow with four children. Today she lives with her youngest son in the Han-Uul district of Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. Her husband passed away last year and her three grown-up children are all married and live with their own families. The youngest son, who lives with his mother, is a taxi driver.

In 2000, Doljinsuren started selling milk from the two cows that she owned. Currently, she has four milk cows and some loyal customers. With the help of her daughter-in-law, she hopes to expand the business by increasing to ten the number of cows she owns. She has always wanted to have a successful milk business so that she can pass on her good business to her youngest son and his wife. She requests a loan to buy fodder for her cows.

loans.use: To buy fodder for her cows

loans.name: Rosemary

texts.en: Rosemary is 34 years old and married with two children. She lives in Delta State, Nigeria. She sells provisions and drinks and she has been in this business since 2009. She needs the loan amount of N 100,000 to purchase more provisions and drinks to sell. She is a LAPO client. She says thanks to all that made this loan possible.

loans.use: To purchase more provisions  and drinks to sell

loans.name: Roseline

texts.en: Roseline sells provisions and drinks. She started this business in 2005. She hopes for the loan amount of NGN 120,000 to purchase more provisions and drinks to sell. She is 48 years old and married with 7 children. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more provisions and drinks to sell

loans.name: Salma

texts.en:
Salma baji is the wife of M. A. who lives in a city named Raiwind, Pakistan. She owns a two-room brick house and has been living in it with her family for the past ten years. Her husband is an auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle) driver. He drives a rented auto-rickshaw. Salma baji runs a dairy business. She sells milk to share the financial burden with her husband because, as we all know, the economic conditions are getting worse day by day and it is most difficult to rely on one person’s income.

Salma baji is applying for a loan to buy an auto-rickshaw for her husband so that he able to receive the whole earnings of his work.

loans.use: To buy an auto-rickshaw for her husband

loans.name: Ganbaatar

texts.en:
Ganbaatar R. lives with his wife and three children in the Bayanzurh district of Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. His oldest daughter is a cook in a small local restaurant. The other two children are high-school students. They live in a ger (a traditional mobile tent) built on land owned by their cousin, since Ganbaatar's family does not own one.

Since 2000, Ganbaatar and his wife have been reselling second-hand clothes in the Narantuul market, the largest outdoor market in Ulaanbaatar. Since their capital for the business is quite small, they do not make much profit. They hope to expand the business as the capital allows.

Even though they always want to save their small profit to reinvest in their business for expansion, they can’t save any money for later due to the large expense of the family of five. Ganbaatar says, "It would be like a dream come true if my family could live on land that we own. Hopefully, I will be able to send at least one of my children to a university." He requests a loan to buy more second-hand clothes and thus to increase their business capital.

Tsetseghand, Ganbaatar's wife, is pictured at their clothing stall.

loans.use: To buy more used clothes to sell

loans.name: Marcelina

texts.en:
Mrs. Marcelina C., 62 years old, is married to Rudy, a fisherman. They have five children and all of them are married.

Mrs. C. has been a member of Paglaum MPC under the PDP-LP microfinance program since 2004. She has religiously paid all her loan obligations. She was encouraged to be a member of Paglaum in order to obtain a loan for her project and to support their cost of living.

Now, Mrs. C. has requested a loan of PHP 15,000 to purchase a fishing net and other fishing accessories. Her project is still in progress and she hopes to have another fishing net for them to gain from and to support the day-to-day needs of the family.

loans.use: To purchase a fishing net and other fishing accessories
